ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 3-1—3-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS, CATS, AND OTHER SMALL ANIMALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-597, § 1, adopted September 27, 2016, repealed art. II, §§ 3-16—3-32 and enacted a new art. II, §§ 3-16—3-32 as set out herein. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2006-299, adopted August 29, 2006. 
 
Sec. 3-16. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Animal is any living creature, including but not limited to the following: dogs, cats, cows, horses, birds, fish, mammals, reptiles, fowl, and livestock, but specifically excluding human beings. 
Animal control officer shall mean any person designated by the City of Cedar Hill to act for the city to impound animals, control animals running at large, and as otherwise provided and required in this chapter. 
Animal shelter shall mean a sheltered kennel facility designated to keep abandoned, at large, quarantined, or other animals safe until claimed, adopted, or euthanized in accordance with this article. 
Animal shelter manager shall mean the person designated as the manager of the animal shelter or that person's designee. 
At large shall mean not completely confined by a building, wall, or fence of sufficient strength or construction to restrain the dog on the owner's property. The dog must be restrained by either a leash, chain, or appropriate type of restraint held in the hands of the owner or secured to a permanent fixture within the limits of the owner's private property. It shall be prima facie evidence that a dog is at large if the owner is physically unable to restrain the dog. 
Board means the Texas Board of Health. 
Bodily injury shall mean injury to a human or animal which produces pain, trauma, loss of blood or damage to tissue, and which further causes or reasonably should cause an owner of the injured animal or the injured human to seek medical treatment, and shall include injury resulting from the victim, whether human or animal, attempting to escape or prevent contact with the injuring animal(s). 
Cat shall mean felis catus. 
Cruelly treated includes tortured; seriously overworked; unreasonably abandoned; unreasonably deprived of necessary food, care, medical treatment, or shelter; cruelly confined; or caused to fight with another animal. 
Dangerous animal means: 
(1)  An animal, including a dog, that makes an unprovoked attack on a human, domestic animal or livestock, which causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the animal was kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the animal from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
(2)  An animal, including a dog, that commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the animal was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the animal from leaving the enclosure on its own, and those acts cause a person reasonably to believe that the animal will attack and cause bodily injury to that person. 
(3)  A police dog shall not be considered dangerous if the attack, bite, or mauling occurred during an arrest or other action of a peace officer while the peace officer was using the dog for law enforcement purposes. 
Dog shall mean canis familiaris. 
Domestic animal means any of various animals that have been tamed and made fit for a human environment. 
Euthanize shall mean to cause the death of an animal by a method which: 
(1)  Rapidly produces unconsciousness and death without visible evidence of pain or distress. 
(2)  Utilizes anesthesia produced by an agent that causes painless loss of consciousness and death following such loss of consciousness. 
Emergency euthanizing means the same as euthanize with the exception of the animal being in a non-controlled environment i.e., not located in the animal shelter. 
High risk rabies carrier animal species that is more prone to carry rabies (i.e. skunks, coyotes, raccoons, bats, and fox.) 
Licensed veterinarian shall mean a veterinarian licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the State of Texas. 
Livestock shall mean horses, mules, cows, hogs, goats, sheep and llamas of any and all kind, and shall include both the male and female species of such animals, but not including swine or miniature swine. 
(1)  Small livestock shall mean goats, sheep, llamas of any and all kind, and shall include both the male and female species of such animals. 
(2)  Large livestock shall mean horses, mules, cows, and hogs of any and all kind, and shall include both the male and female species of such animals. 
Local animal control authority means the animal control department and animal control officer(s). 
Nuisance shall mean any action of ownership or control of an animal that unreasonably endangers the life, health, safety or welfare of any person or animal; or an action that would offend the senses of a reasonable person; or any action that unreasonably obstructs the comfortable use of another's property. 
Owner shall mean any person owning, keeping, or harboring an animal within the corporate limits of the city. 
Quarantine means strict confinement of an animal specified in an order by the local animal control authority or its designee: 
(1)  On the private premises of the animal's owner or at a facility approved by the local animal control authority or its designee; and 
(2)  Under restraint by closed cage or paddock or in any other manner approved by the local animal control authority. 
Rabies means an acute viral disease of man and animal affecting the central nervous system and usually transmitted by an animal bite. 
Rabies vaccination means an immunization against the rabies virus. 
Secure enclosure means a fenced area or structure that is: 
(1)  Locked; 
(2)  Capable of preventing the entry of the general public, including children; 
(3)  Capable of preventing the escape or release of a dog; 
(4)  Clearly marked as containing a dangerous dog; and 
(5)  In conformance with the requirements for enclosures established by the local animal control authority. 
Shelter means a structure adequate in size to accommodate the animal's body height and weight; that is fully enclosed on three (3) sides; roofed; and that has a dry solid floor. The interior must remain dry and be protected from the elements at all times and which shall provide either natural or artificial shade for the animal to avoid the direct sunlight. 
Stray means roaming with no physical restraint beyond the premises of an animal's owner or keeper. 
Wild animal means an animal that is defined in chapter 3, article IV of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cedar Hill, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-17. - Reserved.  
Sec. 3-18. - Rabies vaccination. 
(a)  Rabies control authority. Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code § 826.017, as amended, the local animal control authority is hereby designated as the local rabies control authority. 
(b)  Vaccination required. 
(1)  For purposes of this section only, the term "animal" means any animal that is required by state law to have rabies vaccinations. 
(2)  The owner of each animal shall have such it vaccinated against rabies before four (4) months of age and shall obtain a booster for the animal within twelve (12) months of the initial vaccination. After the animal has received its booster, the animal shall be revaccinated: 
a.  No longer than every twelve (12) months thereafter for one-year-dose vaccinations; or, 
b.  No longer than every thirty-six (36) months thereafter for three-year-dose vaccinations. 
(3)  Any person moving into the city from a location outside the city, and has not had an animal vaccinated within the previous year, shall comply with this section within ten (10) days after having moved into the city. 
(4)  A person acquiring a dog or cat under section 3-21(a)(5) shall present to the animal shelter proof of vaccination within three (3) days of acquiring the dog or cat. 
(5)  No rabies vaccine shall be administered until the required observation period has expired whenever an animal has inflicted a bite on any person or another animal. 
(c)  Certificate of vaccination. Upon vaccination, the veterinarian shall issue to the owner of the animal a certificate of vaccination. The veterinarian shall retain a duplicate copy. The certificate shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the vaccinated animal; 
(2)  The date of vaccination; 
(3)  The type of rabies vaccine used including lot and expiration date; 
(4)  The year and number on the rabies vaccination tag; and 
(5)  The breed, age, color, and sex of the vaccinated animal. 
(d)  Rabies vaccination tags. 
(1)  Upon vaccination, the veterinarian shall issue to the owner of the animal metal rabies vaccination tag. The tag shall: 
a.  Be made of a metal material; 
b.  Be serially numbered to correspond with the certificate of vaccination number; 
c.  Bear: 
1.  The year of issuance; and 
2.  The name, address and phone number of the issuing veterinarian. 
(2)  The rabies vaccination tag shall be affixed to a collar, which must be worn while in a public place. 
(3)  If a valid and current rabies vaccination tag is lost, stolen, or destroyed, the owner of the dog or cat shall obtain a duplicate tag. 
(4)  The certificate of vaccination and the rabies vaccination tag shall be valid only for the animal for which it was originally issued. 
(e)  Display proof of vaccination. No person who owns or harbors an animal shall refuse or fail to exhibit a copy of the certificate of vaccination upon demand by the local animal control authority or peace officer. 
(f)  Harboring unvaccinated animal. No person shall harbor any animal that has not been vaccinated against rabies, as required by this article. 
(g)  Confidentiality of certain information in rabies vaccination certificate. 
(1)  Information contained in a rabies vaccination certificate or in any record compiled from the information contained in one (1) or more certificates that identifies or tends to identify an owner or an address, telephone number, or other personally identifying information of an owner of a vaccinated animal is confidential and not subject to disclosure under V.T.C.A., Texas Government Code Ch. 552. 
(2)  The information may be disclosed only to a governmental entity for purposes related to the protection of public health and safety. No person who receives the information shall disclose the information under V.T.C.A., Texas Government Code Ch. 552, and no person shall use the information for a purpose that does not directly relate to the protection of public health and safety. 
(3)  A person who violates this subdivision commits an offense under V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code § 826.0211, and is subject to the penalties described under that section. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-19. - Dog or cat exposed to rabies. 
For any dog or cat known to have been exposed or is reasonably believed to have been exposed to rabies, the following is required: 
(1)  A dog or cat having current rabies vaccination must be re-vaccinated immediately and quarantined in accordance with section 3-25(d) through (i) for a period of not less than forty-five (45) days. 
(2)  A dog or cat not having current rabies vaccination should be humanely euthanized; or, the owner of such dog or cat may, at the owner's expense and in a manner prescribed by the local animal control authority, quarantine the dog or cat. The dog or cat must be vaccinated immediately following exposure and quarantined for a period of not less than ninety (90) days. The dog or cat shall be re-vaccinated no sooner than thirty (30) days prior to its release from quarantine. 
(3)  If the dog or cat is required to be quarantined under this section, the quarantine shall be at an approved veterinarian clinic at the owner's expense or, if authorized by the Local Control Authority, home quarantined. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-20. - Certain animals prohibited in public places; running at large. 
(a)  No person shall allow in a public place any animal of fierce, dangerous, or vicious propensity or any female animal in its estrus cycle. 
(b)  No person shall allow a dog to be at large within the city. 
(c)  If a dog or cat is found upon the premises of another person, the person may confine the dog or cat in a humane manner until the local animal control authority impounds the dog or cat. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-21. - Impoundment of certain animals. 
(a)  Dog at large. 
(1)  The local animal control authority may impound a dog at large. 
(2)  The local animal control authority may impound a cat at the discretion of the owner or residence of the property in which the cat was found. 
(3)  A dog or that is impounded shall be placed in the animal shelter or at the discretion of the local animal control authority and for good cause shown may be released to the owner. Any dog or cat that is impounded two (2) or more times may be declared a nuisance. 
A hearing must be held within ten (10) days from the impound date, to determine if the dog or cat is a nuisance. If the dog or cat is declared a nuisance the dog or cat must be permanently removed from the corporate city limits of Cedar Hill within thirty (30) days of the date of finding. Failure to follow these procedures shall constitute another violation. 
(4)  When a dog or cat is impounded, the animal shelter shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner of the impounded dog or cat, provided however any animal not claimed within seventy-two (72) becomes property of animal shelter. 
(5)  If the dog or cat has not been claimed within a reasonable time frame or has life threatening injuries, or illness after it has been impounded, the dog or cat shall, at the discretion of the animal shelter manager, be either euthanized, be made available for adoption, or be released to an organization approved by the animal shelter manager. 
(6)  An owner of a dog or cat that has been impounded shall be allowed to take custody of the dog or cat from the animal shelter once the following requirements have been met: 
a.  All applicable fees in article V, section 3-100 have been paid; and 
b.  If the owner could not provide proof of current rabies vaccination, the owner shall within three (3) days present to animal shelter proof that the dog or cat has been vaccinated. 
c.  The owner agrees to have the dog or cat spayed or neutered in accordance with section 3-22. 
(b)  Cruelly treated animal. 
(1)  The local animal control authority may, when it has reason to believe that an animal has been or is being cruelly treated, apply to the municipal court for a warrant to seize the animal, unless exigent circumstances exist and the animal must be seized immediately to avoid harm, injury, or death. 
(2)  On a showing of probable cause to believe that the animal has been or is being cruelly treated, the court shall issue the warrant and set a time within ten (10) calendar days of the date of issuance of the warrant for a hearing to determine whether the animal has been cruelly treated. 
(3)  The local animal control authority shall execute the warrant and cause the animal to be impounded. 
(4)  The municipal court shall give to the owner of the animal written notice of the time and place of the hearing. 
(5)  The hearing and disposition of the animal shall be in accordance with V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code Ch. 821, Subch. B. 
(c)  Dangerous dog. A dangerous dog shall be impounded in accordance with section 3-27. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-22. - Spay or neuter. 
(a)  All dogs and cats within the city are required to be spayed/neutered, unless they are under the control of an individual. 
(b)  All impounded dogs and cats are required to be spayed/neutered within thirty (30) days of release from impoundment; and 
(c)  Implanted with a microchip at the expense of the owner before release from the local animal shelter. 
(d)  It is an exception to the requirements in subsection (b) if the animal shelter manager determines that: 
(1)  The owner of the dog or cat is a member of a club which is associated with a national registry, national breed club or local all-breed club, and does not sell twelve (12) or more intact animals per year; 
(2)  The dog or cat was impounded due to force vis major; 
(3)  The dog or cat was impounded due to fire, criminal or negligent acts of a third party who does not reside at the animal owner's residence. Additionally, verification of the incident must be presented to the animal shelter manager in the form of a police or fire report, or the sworn testimony or affidavit of police or fire personnel. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-23. - Limitation on number of dogs or cats kept. 
(a)  No person shall keep more than four (4) dogs, cats, or a combination thereof, that are older than four (4) months of age on a residential lot. 
(b)  Permit for additional dogs or cats. 
(1)  Any person who desires to keep more dogs, cats, or a combination thereof, than what is allowed by this section may apply to the local animal control authority for a permit to keep the additional animal(s). 
(2)  The applicant shall provide the local animal control authority satisfactory proof from adjoining property owners that there is no objection to the issuance of the permit. 
(3)  A permit may not be issued until the local animal control authority conducts an inspection of the premises to ensure the conditions are reasonably adequate to maintain the number of dogs and/or cats sought. The local animal control authority may specify conditions, limitations, and restrictions in the permit. 
(4)  The permit shall expire one (1) year after the issuance date. 
(5)  The local animal control authority may revoke the permit prior to its expiration if: 
a.  The conditions at the premises are no longer reasonably adequate to maintain the number of dogs and/or cats allowed by the permit; 
b.  The owner fails to comply with the conditions, limitations, and restrictions specified in the permit; or 
c.  A persistent nuisance occurs. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions in subsection (a), an owner may keep at any one (1) time one (1) litter of either puppies or kittens not older than four (4) months of age. 
(d)  All pens and enclosures where dogs or cats are kept shall be maintained and kept in such a manner as not to create a nuisance as defined in section 3-26. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-24. - Reporting animal bite or animal exposed to rabies. 
(a)  Any person having knowledge of a person bitten or scratched by a dog, cat, ferret or high risk rabies carrier shall report the incident or animal to the local animal control authority no later than twenty-four (24) hours after becoming aware of the incident or exposure. The report shall include the name and address of any victim and the owner of the animal, if known, and any other information that may help identify and locate the animal. 
(b)  The owner of an animal that has been exposed to rabies, or the owner of an animal the owner knows or reasonably believes to be rabid or to have been exposed to rabies, shall report the animal to the local animal control authority. 
(c)  Any dog, cat, or ferret that bites, scratches, or otherwise attacks any person within the city limits, shall be quarantined in accordance with section 3-25(d) through (i). 
(d)  The local animal control authority shall report and investigate any dog, cat, or ferret bite using standardized reporting forms provided by the Texas Department of Health and the city. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-25. - Animal quarantine. 
(a)  Any dog, cat, or ferret that bites, scratches, or otherwise creates a condition which may expose or transmit the rabies virus to a human being shall be impounded immediately unless the local animal control authority determines that circumstances exist which would not warrant quarantine. 
(b)  The owner shall voluntarily, or upon demand by the local animal control authority, submit for quarantine a dog, cat, or ferret that has bitten, scratched, or otherwise created a condition which may have exposed or transmitted the rabies virus to any human being. 
(c)  The quarantine period shall be for a minimum of ten (10) days beginning on the date the incident occurred, or longer as the local animal control authority may deem necessary. The animal shall be quarantined in accordance with the Texas Health and Safety Code. 
(d)  Quarantine shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The quarantined dog, cat, or ferret upon showing clinical signs of rabies, shall be immediately destroyed and the head submitted by the animal control officer to the nearest Texas Department of Health laboratory for testing. 
(2)  The dog, cat, or ferret placed in quarantine shall not be released without prior notification to and written approval from the local animal control authority. 
(3)  Home quarantine, if approved by the local animal control authority, must satisfy the following conditions: 
a.  A secure enclosure is available and is approved by the local animal control authority; 
b.  The dog or cat is currently vaccinated against rabies; 
c.  The animal control officer must observe the dog, cat, or ferret on the first and last day of the quarantine period; 
d.  The owner of the dog, cat, or ferret shall notify the animal control officer if the dog, cat, or ferret escapes, becomes or appears to be sick, or dies; and, in case of death of the dog, cat, or ferret while under quarantine, shall immediately surrender the dead dog, cat, or ferret to the animal control officer for diagnostic purposes; 
e.  The dog, cat, or ferret was not running at large at the time of the incident; and 
f.  The dog, cat, or ferret is isolated from all other animals and human beings, other than the individual(s) who owns the animal. 
g.  If the dog or cat was not in violation of any city ordinance or statue at the time of the bite. 
(e)  When submitted for quarantine, the owner shall provide the name, address and any other relevant information about the dog, cat, or ferret to the local animal control authority. 
(f)  The owner of a quarantined dog, cat, or ferret shall pay all reasonable costs of the quarantine or related fees within seventy-two (72) hours of notification to the owner or the dog, cat, or ferret becomes property of the animal shelter. 
(g)  A dog, cat, or ferret that has been quarantined may be released by the local animal control authority after a licensed veterinarian or local animal control authority has determined that the quarantined dog, cat, or ferret does not show clinical signs of rabies, and at the end of the of the observation period: 
(1)  The owner provides proof of current vaccination or within three (3) days, excluding ferrets; 
(2)  All applicable fees have been paid; and 
(3)  The dog or cat is not being held for legal proceedings. 
(h)  No person shall, without prior approval of the local animal control authority, destroy or remove from the city any dog, cat, or ferret that has bitten a person or that has been placed under quarantine. 
(i)  The carcass of a dead dog, cat, or ferret exposed to rabies or suspected of having been rabid shall, upon demand by the local animal control authority, be surrendered to the local animal control authority. 
(j)  No person shall fail or refuse to surrender a dog, cat, or ferret for quarantine or destruction when ordered by the local animal control authority. 
(k)  No person shall interrupt the observation period or interfere with quarantine process. 
(1)  Wild animals shall be humanely euthanized and shall be submitted to a certified Texas Department of Health laboratory for testing. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-26. - Nuisance. 
(a)  Defined. The following conditions are considered to be a nuisance to the citizens of Cedar Hill and are hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to cause, suffer, or permit: 
(1)  The keeping of any animal that causes loud, unusual or frequent barking, howling, or other noise that would disturb the peace and quiet of a person of ordinary sensibility; 
(2)  The keeping of any animal in such a manner as to endanger public health or cause an unsanitary condition due to the accumulation of animal waste that causes foul and offensive odors, or which is considered to be a hazard to any other animal or human being; 
(3)  The keeping of bees or any animal in such a manner as to deny the lawful use of adjacent property or endanger personal health and welfare; 
(4)  Any animal pens, stables, enclosures, and property not kept free from carrion or any putrid material; 
(5)  Any house, building, business, lot, yard, pen, enclosure, or ground in which an animal is kept that is unsanitary or offensive to a person of ordinary sensibility residing in the vicinity thereof, or to the public at large; 
(6)  The keeping of any animal that is tethered, chained, or fastened in a manner in which the animal has access to any public sidewalk or street. No animal shall be tethered, chained, or fastened in a manner as to cause injury or pain to the animal or to deny the animal access to food, water, or shelter; 
(7)  Any owned animal that deposits excreta on public or private property, not without retrieving and properly disposing of the excreta; 
(8)  Any pen or enclosure that emits an odor detectable from any adjacent property; or 
(9)  A pen or enclosure that is maintained or kept in any manner that breeds flies or in any manner that causes injury to the health of the public or to any person residing in the vicinity of the pen or enclosure; 
(10)  A dog or cat that has been impounded two (2) or more times; 
(11)  The keeping of an animal in a manner that is considered to be cruel treatment, which may include but not limited to: being tortured; seriously overworked; unreasonably abandoned; unreasonably deprived of necessary food, care, medical treatment, or shelter; cruelly confined or caused to fight with another animal. 
(b)  Determination. Each of the foregoing conditions is deemed to be a nuisance to the citizens of Cedar Hill (herein referred to as a "nuisance"). In addition to the foregoing nuisance, the local animal control authority may determine whether other conditions constitute a nuisance. 
(c)  Abatement. With the exception of subsection (1), (6), (10), and (11) above, a nuisance must be abated within ten (10) days of the notice to abate provided to the owner by the local animal control authority. Failure to abate the nuisance shall be prima facie evidence in the municipal court that the owner is in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-27. - Dangerous animals. 
(a)  Any animal that has caused bodily injury to or the death of a person, domestic animal or livestock or any animal at large that Animal Control observes to have a dangerous disposition, which may be harmful to humans or other animals shall be seized in accordance with V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code § 822.002 or as provided in this article. 
(b)  Any animal seized or impounded under this section shall be held in accordance with section 3-25, held at the animal shelter or held at an approved shelter or animal boarding facility at the animal owner's expense until the hearing that must be held no later than the tenth day after the date of seizure or impoundment, in accordance with V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code § 822.003 or as provided in this ordinance. If the dangerous animal is at large and not claimed within seventy-two (72) hours, at the discretion of the animal shelter manager, it may be either euthanized, be made available for adoption, or be released to an organization approved by the animal shelter manager. The term expense in this section refers to impoundment fees, citations, boarding fees and any other reasonable fees accrued during this process. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to pay all accrued expenses. 
(c)  If the animal is deemed dangerous, the court shall order the disposition of the animal in accordance with V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code, § 822.003. 
(d)  A dangerous animal ordered destroyed under this section shall be destroyed by either a licensed veterinarian, animal control officer, or an authorized person from the animal shelter. 
(e)  An animal that has been determined to be dangerous by another jurisdiction is prohibited from being kept or maintained within the corporate city limits of the City of Cedar Hill. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-27-1. - Owners of dangerous animals. 
(a)  Requirements. 
(1)  Not later than the 10th day after a person learns that the person is the owner of a dangerous animal, the person shall: 
a.  Register the animal with the local animal control authority for the city in which the animal is kept; 
b.  Restrain the animal at all times on a leash in the immediate control of a person or in a secure enclosure as defined in this article; 
c.  Obtain liability insurance coverage or show financial responsibility in an amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to cover damages resulting from an attack by the animal causing bodily injury to a person or other animal and provide proof of the required liability insurance coverage or financial responsibility to the animal control authority for the area in which the animal is kept; and 
d.  Comply with the following regulations in addition to those in this chapter: 
1.  That the animal shall be kept in a locked and secured enclosure; and 
2.  That the owner posts a conspicuous notice that a dangerous animal is located on the premises. 
(b)  The animal deemed dangerous shall remain in the possession of the animal shelter, local animal control, or its designee until all requirements have been met or all appeals exhausted. 
(1)  The owner of a dangerous animal who does not comply with subsection (a) shall deliver the animal to the animal control authority not later than the 10th day after the owner learns that the animal is dangerous. 
(2)  If, on application of any person, a justice court, county court, or municipal court finds, after notice and hearing as provided by section 822.0423 of the Texas Health and Safety Code that the owner of a dangerous animal has failed to comply with subsection (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section 3-27-1, the court shall order the animal control authority to seize the animal and shall issue a warrant authorizing the seizure. The authority shall seize the animal or order its seizure and shall provide for the impoundment of the animal in secure and humane conditions. 
(3)  The owner shall pay any cost or fee assessed by the municipality or county related to the seizure, acceptance, impoundment, or destruction of the animal. The governing body of the municipality may prescribe by resolution the amount of the fees. 
(4)  The court shall order the animal control authority to humanely destroy the animal if the owner has not complied with subsection (1) no later than the 10th day after the date on which the animal is seized or delivered to the animal control authority. The court shall order the animal control authority to return the animal to the owner if the owner complies with subsection (1) no later than the 10th day after the date on which the animal is seized or delivered to the animal control authority. 
(5)  For purposes of this section, a person learns that the person is the owner of a dangerous animal when: 
a.  The owner knows of an attack described in this article; 
b.  The owner receives written notice that a justice court, county court, or municipal court has found that the animal is a dangerous animal under section 3-27; or 
c.  The owner receives written notice prepared by the animal control authority or police department that the animal is a dangerous animal under this article. 
d.  The term written notice in this section means an official report, citation or subpoena that is delivered to the owner in person, by mail or by any other means in which a reasonable person would believe they have been notified. 
(c)  Determination that animal is dangerous. 
(1)  If a person reports an incident described by this article, the animal control authority may investigate the incident. If, after receiving the sworn statements of any witnesses, the animal control authority determines the animal is a dangerous animal, it shall notify the owner of that fact. 
(2)  An owner, not later than the 10th day after the date the owner is notified that an animal owned by the owner is a dangerous animal, may appeal the determination of the animal control authority to a justice, county, or municipal court of competent jurisdiction. An owner may appeal the decision of the justice, county, or municipal court in the same manner as appeal for other cases from the justice, county, or municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-27-2. - Dogs or coyotes that attack animals. 
The City of Cedar Hill adopts and incorporates herein Texas Health and Safety V.T.C.A. Code § 822.013 as follows: 
(a)  A dog or coyote that is attacking or is about to attack, or has recently attacked livestock, domestic animals, or fowls may be killed by: 
(1)  Any person witnessing the attack; or 
(2)  The attacked animal's owner or a person acting on behalf of the owner if the owner or person has knowledge of the attack. 
(b)  A person who kills a dog as provided by this section is not liable for damages to the owner, keeper, or person in control of the dog. 
(c)  A person who discovers on the person's property a dog known or suspected of having killed livestock, domestic animals, or fowls may detain or impound the dog and return it to its owner or deliver the dog to the local animal control authority. The owner of the dog is liable for all costs incurred in the capture and care of the dog or coyote and all damage done by the dog. 
(d)  The owner, keeper, or person in control of a dog that is known to have attacked livestock, domestic animals, or fowls shall control the dog in a manner approved by the local animal control authority. 
(e)  A person is not required to acquire a hunting license under V.T.C.A. Parks and Wildlife Code § 42.002, to kill a dog or coyote under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-28. - Fencing requirements. 
(a)  Any person(s) owning a dog over the weight of thirty (30) pounds shall keep the dog in a fenced area with the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Minimum of six (6) feet in height, measured from the ground up. 
(2)  Constructed of durable materials. 
(3)  No more than two (2) inch gaps in chain links or gaps in wood fencing. 
(4)  Must be free from damage or defects. 
(5)  Contain entries/exits equipped with locking devices. 
(b)  Owners of dogs that dig, chew, or bite and escape from a fenced area may be required to bury the fencing under the ground. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the homeowner, tenants, or responsible parties occupying the residence to make certain fencing requirements are met. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-29. - Animal traps. 
(a)  The local animal control authority may issue a live trap to any person(s) requesting a trap within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Each person shall complete an animal trap application form prior to receiving the trap. 
(c)  Animal traps should not be set on the day before or the day of a city observed holiday, or during inclement weather. 
(d)  Once an animal has been trapped, the local animal control authority must be notified in a timely manner to prevent injury to the animal. 
(e)  Any person(s) requesting a trap will be responsible for keeping the trap in proper working order, and for the cost to repair or replace a damaged, destroyed, or lost trap. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-30. - Injured or dead animal; disposal fee. 
(a)  Medical costs. Medical costs for treating an injured animal that has been transported by the local animal control authority to a licensed veterinarian for emergency care shall be the responsibility of the owner. A twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee shall be charged to an owner if the local animal control authority delivers the owner's injured animal to a veterinarian or veterinary facility. 
(b)  Destroying injured animal. Any person may humanely destroy an animal that is suffering from a life-threatening injury and no apparent treatment is reasonably available and the destruction is for the sole purpose of not prolonging the suffering. 
(c)  Disposal fees. All deceased animals disposed of by the local animal control authority shall be subject to a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee payable at the time the animal is picked up. 
(d)  Animal pick up and disposal. An owner, who desires the local animal control authority to pick up and dispose the owner's dead dog, cat, or other small animal, shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  The owner shall without unnecessary delay notify the local animal control authority of the animal's death and the owner's desire for the local animal control authority to pick up and dispose of the animal. 
(2)  Any dead dog, cat, or other small animal shall be double bagged in a plastic bag of sufficient size and strength to fully contain the animal. 
(3)  The bagged animal shall be placed at the curb on regular business days, excluding city holidays. 
(4)  The local animal control authority shall immediately pick up the dead animal if on duty, and, if not on duty, as soon as possible. 
(e)  Large animals. Large animals such as but not limited to cows, pigs, and horses, will require the use of a rendering service for removal. The owner of the animal shall be responsible for all costs associated with the disposal. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-31. - Enforcement; powers and duties, 
(a)  The local animal control authority and the police department shall have the authority to enforce this article and issue citations for any violation of this article. 
(b)  If the person to be cited is not present, the local animal control authority or police department may deliver the citation to the alleged offender via certified mail. 
(c)  No person shall interfere with the duties performed by a local animal control authority or police department. 
(d)  The animal control officer or any peace officer shall have the authority to use a tranquilizer gun or electro-muscular interruption device in the lawful discharge of official duties. 
(e)  The animal control officer or any peace officer shall have the authority to use whatever reasonable force is necessary, including deadly force, to protect people, domestic animals or livestock from suffering bodily injury. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Sec. 3-32. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article may be issued a citation. Such violation shall constitute a misdemeanor offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall subject the offender to a fine in an amount not to exceed: 
(1)  Two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) if the provision violated governs public health or sanitation; 
(2)  The amount fixed by state law if the violation is one for which the state has a fixed fine; or 
(3)  Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for all other offenses. 
(b)  Each day the said violation is committed or continues shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 2016-597, § 2, 9-27-16)  
Secs. 3-33—3-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK 
 
Sec. 3-46. - Definition. 
As used in this article, "adult age" shall mean the customarily accepted weaning age for a given animal. 
(Code 1976, § 3-43(5); Ord. No. 80-555, § 3, 3-25-80) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-3.  
Sec. 3-47. - Certain farm animals may be kept for educational purposes. 
Certain farm animals including rabbits, poultry, sheep, swine, goats, horses and cattle may be housed, pastured and fed within the city limits and the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city for certain educational purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 3-41; Ord. No. 80-555, § 1, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-48. - Eligibility to keep certain animals. 
In order to keep any of the farm animals listed in section 3-47 of this article for educational purposes, the person responsible for the care and feeding of the animal or animals shall be enrolled as a student in a vocational agriculture course sanctioned by the state education agency, and such animals must be maintained by the student as a vocational agriculture project the maintenance of which will affect that student's grade. 
(Code 1976, § 3-42; Ord. No. 80-555, § 2, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-49. - Number of animals that may be kept. 
The number of animals that may be kept for educational purposes shall be limited as follows: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to maintain for educational purposes a total of more than four (4) adult swine and their immediate offspring, such offspring to be younger than adult age, within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to maintain for educational purposes a total of more than four (4) adult sheep and their immediate offspring per acre or fraction thereof within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to maintain for educational purposes a total of more than twenty-five (25) adult rabbits or poultry per acre or fraction thereof within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to maintain for educational purposes a total of more than four (4) horses or cattle of any age per acre or fraction thereof within the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(Code 1976, § 3-43(1)—(4); Ord. No. 80-555, § 3, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-50. - Not to be kept on certain property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain any sheep, goats, swine, horses or cattle for educational purposes on any residentially zoned lot ten thousand (10,000) square feet or less in area in an approved subdivision development. 
(b)  The minimum lot size on which a project may be maintained on commercially or industrially zoned property shall be sufficient to meet the sanitary standards stated herein. 
(c)  Actual pen area shall be sufficient to meet the requirements of section 3-51 of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 3-44; Ord. No. 80-555, § 4, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-51. - Sanitary conditions to be maintained. 
All animals maintained for educational purposes shall be maintained in sanitary conditions that prevent excessive offensive odors from becoming a constant source of discomfort to persons living in the vicinity, and that prevent an inordinate amount of flies from existing and breeding. 
(Code 1976, § 3-45; Ord. No. 80-555, § 5, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-52. - Keeping animals at school facilities. 
Any animal kept for educational purposes may be kept at school facilities built for that purpose provided that standards established in section 3-51 of this article are met. 
(Code 1976, § 3-46; Ord. No. 80-555, § 6, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-53. - Immunizations. 
All animals maintained for educational purposes shall be given any immunizations ordinarily required for the responsible maintenance of that particular breed and species. Certification of such immunization shall be provided by the vocational agriculture instructor upon request by a city inspector. 
(Code 1976, § 3-47; Ord. No. 80-555, § 7, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-54. - Certification to be provided on request. 
Certification of any animal as a vocational agriculture project shall be provided at the request of a city inspector by the vocational agriculture instructor. 
(Code 1976, § 3-48; Ord. No. 80-555, § 8, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-55. - Animals exempt from other ordinances. 
Any animals kept for educational purposes in compliance with the sections of this article within the city and its extraterritorial jurisdiction are hereby declared to be exempt from enforcement of all other city ordinances or sections thereof regulating the keeping of animals. 
(Code 1976, § 3-49; Ord. No. 80-555, § 9, 3-25-80)  
Sec. 3-56. - Violations. 
Any violation of any section of this article shall be considered a violation of the whole article. Upon determination by a city inspector that a violation of this article exists such violation shall be ordered corrected or abated within ninety (90) days of receipt by the violator of written notice from the inspector that a violation exists. Failure to correct or abate the violation within the time allowed will result in the declaration in writing to the violator and the vocational agriculture instructor by the city inspector that this article does not apply to the animals in question. At such time as nonapplication of this article is declared appropriate, existing ordinances regulating the keeping of animals in the city shall be applied. This article shall be enforced on a citizen complaint basis. 
(Code 1976, § 3-50; Ord. No. 80-555, § 10, 3-25-80)  
Secs. 3-57—3-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WILD ANIMALS AND DANGEROUS WILD ANIMALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, adopted March 26, 2002, amended art. IV in its entirety, §§ 3-71—3-77, and added §§ 3-78—3-80. Formerly, said sections pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 3-71. - Definition. 
Animal registration agency means the Animal Control Office of the City of Cedar Hill, and any of its agents, having authority over the area where a dangerous wild animal is kept. 
Board means the Texas Board of Health. 
Commercial activity means: 
(1)  An activity involving a wild animal or dangerous wild animal conducted for profit that is not inherent to the animal's nature; 
(2)  An activity for which a fee is charged and that is entertainment using or an exhibition of the animal; or 
(3)  The selling, trading, bartering, or auctioning of a wild animal or dangerous wild animal or an animal's body parts. 
Dangerous wild animal means a lion, tiger, ocelot, cougar, leopard, cheetah, jaguar, bobcat, lynx, serval, caracal, hyena, bear, coyote, jackal, baboon, chimpanzee, orangutan, gorilla, or any hybrid of an animal listed in this section. 
Own means to own, harbor, or have custody or control of. 
Owner means any person who owns, harbors, or has custody or control of a dangerous wild animal. 
Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, trust, estate, joint stock company, foundation, or association of individuals. 
Primary enclosure means any structure used to immediately restrict an animal to a limited amount of space, including a cage, pen, run, room, compartment, or hutch. 
Wild animals shall include all types of animals, which commonly exist in a natural unconfined state and are usually not domesticated. This shall apply regardless of the state or duration of captivity. Such animals shall include, but are not limited to: skunks, raccoons, bats, weasels, squirrels, opossums, lesser pandas, binturongs, wolves, hybrids of wolves and canines, elephants, rhinoceroses, foxes, alligators, crocodiles, monkeys, ostriches, emus, prairie dogs, boas, pythons, anacondas, and all forms of poisonous or constrictive reptiles and other like animals. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-72. - Wild animals and dangerous wild animals prohibited. 
(a)  Except as provided by subdivisions (b) and (c), a person may not own a wild animal or a dangerous wild animal inside the city. 
(b)  A person may own a dangerous wild animal: 
(1)  Owned by and in the custody and control of a person performing a commercial activity for a period not to exceed fourteen (14) days; 
(2)  While in the temporary custody or control of a television or motion picture production company during the filming of a television or motion picture production in this city for a period not to exceed fourteen (14) days; 
(3)  While being transported in interstate commerce through the state in compliance with the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. Section 2131 et seq.) and its subsequent amendments and the regulations adopted under that Act; 
(4)  In the control and custody of a person whose only business is supplying nonhuman primates directly and exclusively to biomedical research facilities and who holds a Class "A" or Class "B" dealer's license issued by the secretary of agriculture of the United States under the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. Section 2131 et seq.) and its subsequent amendments; and 
(5)  That is: 
a.  Owned by or in the possession, control, or custody of a person who is a participant in a species survival plan of the American Zoo and Aquarium Association for that species; and 
b.  An integral part of that species survival plan. 
(6)  While in the temporary custody or control of a person who holds a current Wildlife Rehabilitation permit issued by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, where the sole purpose of possessing the animal is for rehabilitation, and the animal is released from the city upon being rehabilitated. 
(c)  A person may own a wild animal: 
(1)  Under the same provisions of subdivision (b); or 
(2)  After obtaining a wild animal permit issued by the animal registration agency. The permit must be renewed annually from the issuance date. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-72.1. - Sell or transfer of wild animal or a dangerous wild animal prohibited. 
A person may not sell or otherwise transfer ownership of a wild animal or a dangerous wild animal to another person from within city, except as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-73. - Liability insurance. 
An owner of a wild animal or dangerous wild animal shall maintain liability insurance coverage in an amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each occurrence for liability for damages for destruction of or damage to property and death or bodily injury to a person caused by the dangerous wild animal. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-74. - Attack by animal; escape of animal; liability. 
(a)  An owner of a wild animal or a dangerous wild animal shall notify the animal registration agency of any attack of a human by the animal within twenty-four (24) hours of the attack. 
(b)  An owner of a wild animal or dangerous wild animal shall immediately notify the animal registration agency and the local law enforcement agency of any escape of the animal. 
(c)  An owner of a wild animal or dangerous wild animal that escapes is liable for all costs incurred in apprehending and confining the animal. 
(d)  The animal registration agency, the police department, or any of its agents shall not be liable to an owner of a wild animal or dangerous wild animal for damages arising in connection with the escape of a dangerous wild animal, including liability for damage, injury, or death caused by the animal during or after the animal's escape, or for injury to or death of the animal as a result of apprehension or confinement of the animal after escape. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-75. - Caging requirements and standards. 
(a)  The board by rule shall establish caging requirements and standards for the keeping and confinement of a dangerous wild animal to ensure that the animal is kept in a manner and confined in a primary enclosure that: 
(1)  Protects and enhances the public's health and safety; 
(2)  Prevents escape by the animal; and 
(3)  Provides a safe, healthy, and humane environment for the animal. 
(b)  An owner of a dangerous wild animal shall keep and confine the animal in accordance with the caging requirements and standards established by the board. 
(c)  An animal registration agency may approve a deviation from the caging requirements and standards established by the board, only if: 
(1)  The animal registration agency has good cause for the deviation; and 
(2)  The deviation: 
a.  Does not compromise the public's health and safety; 
b.  Does not reduce the total area of the primary enclosure below that established by the board; and 
c.  Does not otherwise adversely affect the overall welfare of the animal involved. 
(d)  The animal registration agency may establish separate caging requirements and standards for wild animals. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-76. - Care, treatment, and transportation of animal. 
(a)  For each wild animal and dangerous wild animal, the owner shall comply with all applicable standards of the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. Section 2131 et seq.) and its subsequent amendments and the regulations adopted under that Act relating to: 
(1)  Facilities and operations; 
(2)  Animal health and husbandry; and 
(3)  Veterinary care. 
(b)  An owner of a wild animal and dangerous wild animal shall maintain a separate written log for each animal documenting the animal's veterinary care and shall make the log available to the animal registration agency or its agent on request. The log must: 
(1)  Identify the animal treated; 
(2)  Provide the date of treatment; 
(3)  Describe the type or nature of treatment; and 
(4)  Provide the name of the attending veterinarian, if applicable. 
(c)  When transporting a wild animal or dangerous wild animal, the owner of the animal, or a designated carrier or intermediate handler of the animal, shall comply with all transportation standards that apply to that animal under the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. Section 2131 et seq.) and its subsequent amendments or the regulations adopted under that Act. 
(d)  A person is exempt from the requirements of this section if the person is caring for, treating, or transporting an animal for which the person holds a Class "A" or Class "B" dealer's license or a Class "C" exhibitor's license issued by the secretary of agriculture of the United States under the Animal Welfare Act (7 U.S.C. Section 2131 et seq.) and its subsequent amendments. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-77. - Inspection; permit required; fees. 
(a)  A person authorized to own a dangerous wild animal under subsection 3-77(b) may not own a dangerous wild animal in the city without first obtaining an inspection and possession permit from the animal registration agency. A person authorized to have a wild animal under subsection 3-72(c), may not own a wild animal in the city without first obtaining a wild animal permit from the animal registration agency. 
(b)  A permit may not be issued to a person who is not in compliance with sections 3-73, 3-75, and 3-76 of this article. A permit issued under this article may only be issued to the person who will have possession, custody, and control of the wild animal or dangerous wild animal. 
(c)  At the time a person obtains a permit application, the animal registration agency shall furnish to the applicant a written copy of the requirements to obtain a permit. 
(d)  The animal registration agency may revoke an owner's permit at any time the owner of the animal is in violation of this article. A person may not own a wild animal or dangerous wild inside the city during the period the person's permit is revoked. The animal registration agency may re-issue a permit upon satisfaction that the owner is in compliance with this article. 
(e)  An owner of a wild animal or dangerous wild animal, at all reasonable times, shall allow the animal registration agency or a designated licensed veterinarian to enter the premises where the animal is kept and to inspect the animal, the primary enclosure for the animal, and the owner's records relating to the animal to ensure compliance with this article. 
(f)  The fee charged for obtaining a permit for a wild animal or for a dangerous wild animal shall be established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-78. - Offenses and penalty. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person violates any provision of this article. 
(b)  Each day a person violates a provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  An offense under this article is misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00.) 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-79. - Civil penalty. 
(a)  The city may sue to collect a civil penalty assessed under this article. 
(b)  The city may also recover the reasonable costs of investigation, reasonable attorney's fees, and reasonable expert witness fees incurred by the animal registration agency in the civil action. Costs or fees recovered under this article shall be credited to the operating account from which payment for the animal registration agency's expenditures was made. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 3-80. - Effects of article on other law. 
This article does not affect the applicability of any other law, rule, order, ordinance, or other legal requirement of this city, state or a political subdivision of this state. 
(Ord. No. 2002-104, § 1, 3-26-02)  
Secs. 3-81—3-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ANIMAL SHELTER 
 
Sec. 3-100. - Animal shelter fees. 
(a)  Impoundment and boarding fees. The Tri-City Animal Shelter will charge the following impoundment and other fees: 
First offense, per animal .....$30.00 
Second offense, per animal .....60.00 
Third and subsequent offenses, per animal .....100.00 
(b)  Boarding fees. The owner of an animal that has been impounded at the Tri-City Animal Shelter will be charged a boarding fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per night, including weekends and holidays. 
(c)  Rabies observation fee. The owner of animal that has been quarantined at the Tri-City Animal Shelter for rabies observation will be charged a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per night, including weekends and holidays. 
(d)  Adoption fees and procedures. The fee for the adoption of a dog or cat from the Tri-City Animal Shelter shall be one hundred five dollars ($105.00) for each such animal adopted. Each dog and cat adopted from the Tri-City Animal Shelter shall be sterilized, vaccinated for rabies and implanted with a microchip prior to adoption. If an animal cannot be sterilized prior to adoption, the person adopting the animal shall have the animal sterilized within thirty (30) days from the date of the adoption. If an animal cannot be vaccinated for rabies prior to adoption, the person adopting the animal shall have the animal vaccinated before the animal reaches sixteen (16) weeks of age. 
(e)  Surrender fee. 
(1)  Any person not a resident of Cedar Hill, DeSoto, or Duncanville who wishes to surrender a dog or cat older than four (4) months of age may do so for a twenty dollar ($20.00) fee. 
(2)  A litter of four (4) or less dogs or cats that are under four (4) months of age will be accepted for a thirty dollar ($30.00) fee. Additional animals from the same litter will be accepted at a rate of five dollars ($5.00) per animal. 
(f)  Veterinarian disposal fee. A veterinarian who disposes a dog or cat or other small animal carcass at the Tri-City Animal Shelter will be charged a five dollar ($5.00) disposal fee per carcass. The Tri-City Animal Shelter may refuse to accept an animal carcass. 
(g)  Space limitations. The animal shelter manager is authorized to suspend acceptance of animals from non-residents or animals from outside Cedar Hill, DeSoto or Duncanville due to space limitations or other considerations. 
(Ord. No. 2006-299, § 2, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2007-337, § 1, 9-25-07; Ord. No. 2008-351, § 2, 8-26-08; Ord. No. 2013-500, § 2, 1-8-13)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Building permits. 
The rates to be charged for building permits on structures herein designated shall be inclusive of fees for electrical, plumbing and heating and air conditioning permits and shall be as follows: 
A.  One- and two-family dwelling units: ;hg;$400.00 for the first one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet. 
$400.00 plus $0.60 per square foot over one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet up to two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet. 
$1,150.00 plus $0.40 per square foot over two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet. 
Square footage is based on total square foot under roof to include but not limited to garages, porches, and breezeways. 
B.  Multifamily dwellings other than duplex: $150.00 each unit. 
C.  Commercial, industrial, retaining walls, and other structure, additions or alterations, tenant finish outs:

The plan review fee is due at the time of applying for the building permit and is nonrefundable.

(Ord. No. 2009-381, §§ 1, 2, 4, 4-28-09)

Sec. 4-2. - Same—Application and payment of fee. 
Application for any permit required pursuant to this chapter, as well as the payment of any fee required by this chapter, shall be made to the inspection department of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-15.8; Ord. No. 79-537, § 8, 10-23-79)  
Sec. 4-3. - Same—Additional fees for failure to comply. 
Any person who shall commence any work for which a permit is required (under the building, mechanical, plumbing and electrical codes of the city) without first having obtained a permit therefor shall, if subsequently permitted to obtain a permit, pay double the permit fee fixed by ordinance. This section shall not apply to emergency construction. The city council shall enforce this section at its discretion. 
(Code 1976, § 4-15.9; Ord. No. 79-537, § 9, 10-23-79)  
Sec. 4-4. - Same—City school district. 
Notwithstanding any fee schedule to the contrary, the building permit fees to be charged to public school buildings within the Cedar Hill Independent School District shall be fifty (50) percent of the fee that would have been assessed pursuant to such fee structure heretofore adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 88-977, § 2, 6-14-88) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-977, § 2, adopted June 14, 1988, being not expressly amendatory of this Code, has been codified as § 4-4 at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 4-5—4-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING APPEALS AND ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration generally, Ch. 2; attendance of board, commission members at meetings, etc., § 2-1. 
 
Sec. 4-21. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created a board to be known as the building appeals and advisory board. Such board shall consist of nine (9) members, all of whom shall reside within the corporate limits of the city. The nine (9) members of the board shall be appointed by the city council, and shall consist of the following persons: 
(1)  One (1) licensed and registered master plumber; 
(2)  One (1) licensed and registered master electrician; 
(3)  Two (2) building contractors; 
(4)  One (1) mechanical contractor; 
(5)  Four (4) engineers, architects or persons without building profession expertise, or any combination thereof. 
The building official of the city shall also be an ex officio member of the board. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 4, 12-18-84; Ord. No. 91-081, § 1, 7-9-91)  
Sec. 4-22. - Tenure of office. 
(a)  The appointive members of the building appeals and advisory board shall hold office for a period of two (2) years from the dates of their appointments and qualifications or until their successors have been appointed and qualified. 
(b)  One (1) master plumber, master electrician, building contractor, mechanical contractor, and one (1) engineer, architect or person without building profession expertise shall be appointed to terms of office expiring on or about May first of odd-numbered years. The remaining master electrician, master plumber, building contractor, mechanical contractor, and engineer, architect or person without building profession expertise shall be appointed to terms of office expiring on or about May first of even-numbered years. 
(c)  Any appointed member of the board may be removed by the city council for cause. Vacancies within the board shall be filled by appointment of the city council for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 5, 12-18-84)  
Sec. 4-23. - Compensation. 
The appointive members of the building appeals and advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 6, 12-18-84)  
Sec. 4-24. - Organization and procedure. 
(a)  The board created by this article shall select a chairman and shall prescribe a procedure and order of business for the performance of its duties. The building official shall act as, or designate a suitable person to act as secretary to the board. 
(b)  Five (5) members of the board present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and any action taken at any meeting shall require the affirmative vote of a majority of those present and eligible to vote, and in no case less than four (4) affirmative votes. 
(c)  Regular meetings of the board shall be held for the purpose of hearing appeals and rendering interpretations of the building, mechanical, plumbing and electrical codes, and hearing applications for the proposed use of new materials and methods of construction or installation. 
(d)  The board shall keep a minute book in which shall be recorded all transactions and business of the board. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 7, 12-18-84)  
Sec. 4-25. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The board created by this article shall have jurisdiction over all appeals from the decision of the building official which relates to any building installation, and shall have the power to pass upon the true intent and meaning of the provisions of the building, mechanical, plumbing and electrical codes, and to approve such alternate materials and methods of construction or installation as are proved acceptable to the board under the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Whenever the board finds in the building, mechanical, plumbing or electrical code any provision that is inadequate or obsolete, it shall be the duty of such board to recommend the necessary amendments to the city council through the city manager. 
(c)  The board shall hear and determine any appeal by a general contractor from a decision by the building official to suspend, revoke or deny a permit under article XXI, registration of general contractors. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 8, 12-18-84; Ord. No. 2007-317, § 1, 6-12-07)  
Sec. 4-26. - Appeal from decision of building official. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by any interpretation of this article or by any decision or ruling by the building official under this article shall have the right to make an appeal to the board created by this article. Such appeal shall be made in writing and shall be duly verified by the person familiar with the facts therein charged and three (3) written copies of the same shall be filed with the city secretary within thirty (30) days of the date of the decision appealed from. A certified check for the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) payable to the city shall accompany such appeal to cover the cost of processing the appeal. The city secretary shall retain one (1) copy of such appeal for the official records of the city and shall refer two (2) copies of the appeal to the chief of the division of building inspection, who shall investigate the facts and report the appeal and the facts to the board. 
(b)  The board shall, within a period of thirty (30) days, hear the appeal and the facts. The building official shall not sit as a member of the board at any time when the board is hearing an appeal from the decision of the building official, and he shall not vote. 
(c)  In hearing such appeal, the board shall not have the power to waive or set aside the requirements of this article and in the case of alternate types of construction or material, shall determine whether or not such alternative types of construction or material are in fact equal to the standards of this chapter, considering adequacy, stability, strength, sanitation and safety to the public health and welfare. 
(d)  The board shall render a final decision which shall be filed with the city secretary. 
(e)  The building official, or the board at its own volition, shall have the authority to consider alternate materials and construction methods and approve the use of same as equal to the standards set out in the adopted codes of the city. All such approvals and conditions under which they are approved shall be specific, shall be reasonable, shall not create an injustice and shall be made a matter of public record. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 9, 12-18-84)  
Sec. 4-27. - Appeals to the court. 
(a)  Any person who may feel himself aggrieved by any action or decision of the board created by this article, after exhausting the remedies provided in section 4-26 of this article, may file a suit within thirty (30) days after receiving notice of the board's final order, in a district court of Dallas County, to annual or vacate the order of the board. Such suit shall be filed against the board as defendant and service of process may be made upon the board by serving the city secretary. The suit shall be tried as other civil cases, the burden of proof devolving upon the plaintiff assailing the order of the board. 
(b)  In such suits the board shall be defended by the city attorney until final determination of the proceedings contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 84-744, § 10, 12-18-84)  
Secs. 4-28—4-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING INSPECTOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— City officers and employees generally, § 2-31 et seq.; duties of building inspector in relation to moving of buildings, § 4-166. 
 
Sec. 4-41. - Office created. 
The office of "building inspector" of the city is hereby created, and the executive official in charge shall be known as the building inspector. The building inspector shall be appointed by the city council, and his appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service; provided that, he may be removed from office for cause after full opportunity has been given him to be heard by the council. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2; Ord. No. 81-596, § 2, 6-2-81)  
Sec. 4-42. - Duties. 
It shall be the duty of the building inspector to enforce all provisions of this Code and laws relating to the construction, alteration, removal and demolition of buildings and structures. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3; Ord. No. 81-596, § 3, 6-2-81)  
Sec. 4-43. - Right of entry. 
The building inspector, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon proper identification, shall have the authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. 
(Code 1976, § 4-4; Ord. No. 81-596, § 4, 6-2-81)  
Sec. 4-44. - Trench safety. 
The building inspector shall be required to attend the trench safety course sponsored by the Associated General Contractors. 
(Ord. No. 88-959, § 5, 2-23-88) 
Cross reference— Trench safety program, § 4-311 et seq.

ARTICLE IV. - INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Electrical code, § 4-81 et seq.; mechanical code, § 4-101 et seq.; plumbing code, § 4-116 et seq.; fire prevention code, § 6-21 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4-61. - Adoption of the 2015 International Building Code. 
The 2015 International Building Code is hereby adopted and incorporated in its entirety as though fully set out at length herein, save and except such portions as are herein after deleted, modified or amended and the provisions of such code shall be controlling in the installation, alteration or repair of all buildings and the inspection thereof; within the corporate limits of the City of Cedar Hill, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2009-378, §§ 1, 2, 3-24-09; Ord. No. 2012-487, §§ 1, 2, 9-25-12; Ord. No. 2017-632, § 2, 11-14-17)  
Sec. 4-62. - 2015 International Building Code additional requirements and amendments. 
(1)  Section 901.6.1.1 is added to read as follows: 
901.6.1.1 standpipe testing. Building owners/managers must maintain and test standpipe systems as per nfpa 25 requirements. The following additional requirements shall be applied to the testing that is required every 5 years: 
1.  The piping between the Fire Department Connection (FDC) and the standpipe shall be back flushed when material is present and also hydrostatically tested for all FDC's on any type of standpipe system. Hydrostatic testing shall also be conducted in accordance with NFPA 25 requirements for the different types of standpipe systems. 
2.  For any manual (dry or wet) standpipe system not having an automatic water supply capable of flowing water through the standpipe, the tester shall connect hose from a fire hydrant or portable pumping system (as approved by the fire code official) to each FDC, and flow water through the standpipe system to the roof outlet to verify that each inlet connection functions properly. Confirm that there are no open hose valves prior to introducing water into a dry standpipe. There is no required pressure criteria at the outlet. Verify that check valves function properly and that there are no closed control valves on the system. 
3.  Any pressure relief, reduction, or control valves shall be tested in accordance with the requirements of NFPA 25. All hose valves shall be exercised. 
4.  If the FDC is not already provided with approved caps, the contractor shall install such caps for all FDC's as required by the fire code official. 
5.  Upon successful completion of standpipe test, place a blue tag (as per Texas Administrative Code, Fire Sprinkler Rules for Inspection, Test and Maintenance Service (ITM) Tag) at the bottom of each standpipe riser in the building. The tag shall be check-marked as "Fifth Year" for type of ITM, and the note on the back of the tag shall read "5 Year Standpipe Test" at a minimum. 
6.  The procedures required by the Texas Administrative Code, Fire Sprinkler Rules with regard to Yellow Tags and Red Tags or any deficiencies noted during the testing, including the required notification of the local Authority Having Jurisdiction (fire code official) shall be followed. 
7.  Additionally, records of the testing shall be maintained by the owner and contractor, if applicable, as required by the State Rules mentioned above and NFPA 25. 
8.  Standpipe system tests where water will be flowed external to the building shall not be conducted during freezing conditions or during the day prior to expected night time freezing conditions. 
9.  Contact the fire code official for requests to remove existing fire hose from Class II and III standpipe systems where employees are not trained in the utilization of this firefighting equipment. All standpipe hose valves must remain in place and be provided with an approved cap and chain when approval id given to remove hose by the fire code official. 
(2)  Section 901.6.4 is added to read as follows: 
901.6.4 Systems in high-rise buildings. The owner of a high-rise building shall be responsible for assuring that the fire and life-safety systems required by the Building Code are maintained in an operable condition at all times. Unless otherwise required by the chief, quarterly tests of such systems shall be conducted by approved persons. A written record shall be maintained and shall be made available to the inspection authority. 
(3)  Section 901.6.5 is added to read as follows: 
901.6.5 Smoke-control systems. Mechanical smoke-control systems, such as those in high-rise buildings, buildings containing atria, covered mall buildings and mechanical ventilation systems utilized in smoke proof enclosures and for smoke-removal systems utilized in high-piled combustible storage occupancies, shall be maintained in an operable condition at all times. Unless otherwise required by the chief, quarterly tests of such systems shall be conducted by approved persons. A written record shall be maintained and shall be made available to the inspection authority. 
(4)  Section 903.2.1.1 is amended to read as follows: 
903.2.1.1 Group A-1. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for Group A-1 Occupancies where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  The fire area exceeds 9,000 square feet (836 m 2 ). 
2.  The fire area has an occupant load of 300 or more. 
3.  The fire area is located on a floor other than the level of exit discharge. 
4.  The fire area contains a multi-theater complex. 
(5)  Section 903.2.1.3 is amended to read as follows: 
903.2.1.3 Group A-3. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for Group A-3 Occupancies where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  The fire area exceeds 9000 square feet (836 m 2 ). 
2.  The fire area has an occupant load of 300 or more. 
3.  The fire area is located on a floor other than the level of exit discharge. 
Exception: Areas used exclusively as participant sports areas where the main floor area is located at the same level as the level of exit discharge of the main entrance and exit.

903.2.7 Group M. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings containing a Group M occupancy where one of the following conditions exist:

(9)  Section 903.2.9 is amended to read as follows: 
903.2.9 S-1. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings containing a Group S-1 occupancy where one of the following conditions exist: 
1.  S-1 moderate hazard occupancies 9,000 square feet and greater containing the following: 
Aerosols, Levels 2 and 3 
Aircraft hangar (storage and repair) 
Bags: cloth, burlap and paper 
Bamboos and rattan 
Baskets 
Belting: canvas and leather 
Books and paper in rolls or packs 
Boots and shoes 
Buttons, including cloth covered, pearl or bone 
Cardboard and cardboard boxes 
Clothing, woolen wearing apparel 
Cordage 
Dry boat storage (indoor) 
Furniture 
Furs 
Glues, mucilage, pastes and size 
Grains 
Horns and combs, other than celluloid 
Leather 
Linoleum 
Lumber 
Tobacco, cigars, cigarettes and snuff 
Wax candles 
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout all other Group S-1 moderate hazard occupancies not listed here at 12,000 square feet or greater. 
2.  A Group S-1 fire area is located more than three stories above grade plane. 
3.  The combined area of all S-1 fire areas on all floors, including any mezzanines, exceeds 18,000 square feet (1672 m 2 ). 
4.  A Group S-1 fire area used for the storage of commercial motor vehicles where the fire area exceeds 5,000 square feet (464 m 2 ). 
5.  A Group S-1 occupancy used for the storage of upholstered furniture or mattresses exceeds 2,500 square feet (232 m 2 ).
