(1)  Lack of or improper water closet, lavatory, bathtub or shower in a dwelling unit. 
(2)  Lack of or improper water closets, lavatories and bathtubs or showers per number of guests in a hotel. 
(3)  Lack of or improper kitchen sink. 
(4)  Lack of hot and cold running water to plumbing fixtures in a hotel. 
(5)  Lack of hot and cold running water to plumbing fixtures in a dwelling unit. 
(6)  Lack of adequate heating facilities. 
(7)  Lack of or improper operation of required ventilating equipment. 
(8)  Lack of minimum amounts of natural light and ventilation required by this article. 
(9)  Room and space dimensions less than required by this article. 
(10)  Lack of required electrical lighting. 
(11)  Dampness of habitable rooms. 
(12)  Infestation of insects, vermin or rodents, as determined by the health officer or building official. 
(13)  General dilapidation or improper maintenance. 
(14)  Lack of connection to required sewage disposal system. 
(15)  Lack of adequate garbage and rubbish storage and removal facilities as determined by the health officer or building official. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 19, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-139. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any owner, manager or occupant of a building or structure violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine, upon conviction, as provided in section 4-160.2. Each and every day that the prohibited condition remains and restoration, if required, is not accomplished, it shall constitute a separate offense. These fines shall be in addition to and accumulative of the provisions for the abatement of the nuisance by tearing down and removal and restoration, if required by this article, as well as all other costs provided for by this division. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 20, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-140. - Structural hazards. 
Structural hazards shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Deteriorated or inadequate foundations. 
(2)  Defective or deteriorated flooring or floor supports. 
(3)  Flooring or floor supports of insufficient size to carry imposed loads with safety. 
(4)  Members of walls, partitions or other vertical supports that split, lean, list or buckle due to defective material or deterioration. 
(5)  Members of walls, partitions or other vertical supports that are of insufficient size to carry imposed loads with safety. 
(6)  Members of ceilings, roofs, ceiling and roof supports or other horizontal members which sag, split or buckle due to defective material or deterioration. 
(7)  Members of ceilings, roofs, ceiling and roof supports or other horizontal members that are of insufficient size to carry imposed loads with safety. 
(8)  Fireplaces or chimneys which list, bulge or settle, due to defective material or deterioration. 
(9)  Fireplaces or chimneys which are of insufficient size or strength to carry imposed loads with safety. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 21, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-141. - Hazardous conditions. 
The following conditions are declared to be hazardous: 
(1)  Nuisance. Any nuisance as defined in this article. 
(2)  Hazardous wiring. All wiring, except that which conformed with all applicable laws in effect at the time of installation, and which has been maintained in good condition and is being used in a safe manner. 
(3)  Hazardous plumbing. All plumbing, except that which conformed with all applicable laws in effect at the time of installation and which has been maintained in good condition and is being used in a safe manner. 
(4)  Hazardous mechanical equipment. All mechanical equipment, including vents, except that which conformed with all applicable laws in effect at the time of installation and which has been maintained in good and safe condition. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 22, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-142. - Faulty weather protection. 
Faulty weather protection shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Deteriorated, crumbling or loose plaster. 
(2)  Deteriorated or ineffective waterproofing of exterior walls, roof, foundations or floors, including broken windows or doors. 
(3)  Defective or lack of weather protection for exterior wall coverings, including lack of paint, or weathering due to lack of paint or other approved protective covering. 
(4)  Broken, rotted, split or buckled exterior wall coverings or roof coverings. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 23, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-143. - Fire hazard. 
Fire hazards exist in any building or portion of a building, device, apparatus, equipment, combustible waste or vegetation which, in the opinion of the chief of the fire department, or his authorized representative, is in such a condition as to cause a fire or explosion, or provide a ready fuel to augment the spread and intensity of fire or explosion arising from any cause. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 24, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-144. - Faulty materials of construction. 
Faulty materials of construction shall be all materials of construction, except those which are specifically allowed or approved by this article and the building code and which have been adequately maintained in good and safe condition. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 25, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-145. - Inadequate maintenance. 
Any building or portion of a building which is determined to be an unsafe building in accordance with the building code is inadequately maintained. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 26, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-146. - Inadequate exits. 
Inadequate exits exist in all buildings or portions of buildings not provided with adequate exit facilities as required by this article, except those buildings or portions of buildings whose exit facilities conformed with all applicable laws at the time of their construction, and which have been adequately maintained and increased in relation to any increase in occupant load, alteration, or addition, or any change in occupancy. When an unsafe condition exists through lack of or improper location of exits, additional exits may be required to installed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 27, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-147. - Inadequate fire protection or firefighting equipment. 
Inadequate fire protection or firefighting equipment exist in all buildings or portions thereof which are not provided with the fire-resistive construction or fire extinguishing systems or equipment required by this article, except those buildings or portions of buildings which conformed with all applicable laws at the time of their construction and whose fire-resistive integrity and fire extinguishing systems or equipment have been adequately maintained and improved in relation to any increase in occupant load, alteration or addition, or any change in occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 28, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-148. - Hazardous or unsanitary premises. 
Hazardous or unsanitary premises exist on those premises on which an accumulation of weeds, vegetation, junk, dead organic matter, debris, garbage, offal, rat harborage, stagnant water, combustible materials and similar materials or conditions constitute fire, health or safety hazards. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 29, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-149. - Improper occupancy. 
All buildings or portions of buildings occupied for living, sleeping, cooking or dining purposes which were not designed or intended to be used for such occupancies are improperly occupied. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 30, 10-11-05)  
Subdivision II. - Administration 
 
Sec. 4-150. - Notices and orders of the building official—Commencement of proceedings. 
Whenever the building official has inspected or caused to be inspected any building and has found and determined that such building is a substandard building, he shall commence proceedings to cause the repair, rehabilitation, vacation or demolition of the building. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 31, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-151. - Same—Issuance; contents. 
(a)  The building official shall issue a letter notice to any owner, manager or occupant of a premises which, in the determination of the building official, is in violation of any provision of this ordinance. The notice will be delivered to the owner, manager or occupant in person or by certified mail, return receipt requested. The letter notice shall state the address of the premises, the date of inspection and the condition of the premises requiring repair, replacement, removal, rehabilitation, removal or demolition. The notice letter will provide the owner, manager or occupant a reasonable period of time, and at least thirty (30) days, to comply with the building official's requested action to bring the premises into compliance with this article. 
(b)  If the owner, manager or occupant fails or refuses to comply with the requirements of the letter notice under subsection (a) above, the building official shall issue an official notice and order directed to the occupant, if any, and the record owner of the building. The notice and order shall set a public hearing before the building appeals and advisory board for determination as to whether the building complies with this article's standards and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The names of all persons and entities to which notice is sent. 
(2)  The street address and a legal description sufficient for identification of the premises upon which the building is located. 
(3)  The date of inspection. 
(4)  A statement that the building official has found the building to be substandard with a brief and concise description of the conditions found to render the building substandard under the provisions of this article. 
(5)  A statement of the action recommended to be taken as determined by the building official. 
(6)  A statement that the occupant, owner, manager, lienholder or mortgagee will be required to submit at the hearing proof of the scope of any work undertaken or to be undertaken to comply with this article and the time it will reasonably take to perform the work. 
(7)  The date, time and place of the public hearing. 
(c)  The notice shall be sent to all record owners, lienholders and mortgagees via certified mail, return receipt requested, and via regular mail. 
(d)  The notice of hearing must be posted pursuant to the Texas Open Meetings Act. 
(e)  The notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city on or before the 10 th day before the date of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 32, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-152. - Service and publication. 
(a)  The notice of public hearing and order of any amended or supplemental notice and order shall be served upon the record owner, and posted on the property. One (1) copy shall be served on each of the following, if known to the building official or disclosed from official public records: 
(1)  The holder of any mortgage or deed of trust or other lien or encumbrance of record. 
(2)  The owner or holder of any lease of record; and 
(3)  The holder of any other estate or legal interest of record in or to the building or the land on which it is located. 
The failure of the building official to serve any person required in this section to be served shall not invalidate any proceedings under this subdivision as to any other person duly served or relieve any such person from any duty or obligation imposed on him by the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Method of service. Service of the notice and order shall be made upon all persons entitled thereto by certified mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, and by regular mail, to each such person at his address as it appears on the last equalized assessment roll of the city, or as known to the building official. If no address of any such person so appears or is known to the building official, then a copy of the notice and order shall be mailed, addressed to such person, at the address of the building involved in the proceedings. The failure of any such person to receive such notice shall not affect the validity of any proceedings taken under this subdivision. Service by certified mail in the manner herein provided shall be effective on the date of mailing. 
(c)  Proof of service. Proof of service of the notice and order shall be certified to at the time of service by a written declaration under penalty of perjury executed by the person effecting service, declaring the time, date and manner in which service was made. The declaration, together with any receipt card returned in acknowledgement of receipt by certified mail, shall be affixed to the copy of the notice and order retained by the building official. 
(d)  Publication. The notice of the public hearing shall be posted pursuant to the provisions of the Texas Open Meetings Act. The notice shall be published in the newspaper of general circulation in the city on or before the 10 th day before the date of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 33, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-153. - Hearings. 
(a)  The date of a public hearing under this article shall be not less than ten (10) days after notice has been made and published as set forth in section 4-152 above. 
(b)  If a building is found to be in violation of this article, the building appeals and advisory board may order the owner, lienholder or mortgagee of the building to within thirty (30) days to abate the condition found to constitute a nuisance, or to vacate, repair, remove or demolish the building, unless it is proven at the hearing that the work cannot reasonably be accomplished in thirty (30) days. 
(c)  If the building appeals and advisory board allows more than thirty (30) days for the condition to be abated or the building to be vacated, repaired, removed or demolished, it shall establish specific time schedules for the work to be commenced and completed. The building appeals and advisory board shall not allow the owner, lienholder to mortgagee more than ninety (90) days to abate the condition or to vacate, repair, remove or demolish the building unless a detailed plan and time schedule for the work are submitted at the hearing and it is proven at the hearing that the work cannot be reasonably completed within ninety (90) days because of the scope and/or complexity of the work. 
(Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, adopted August 9, 2016, in effect repealed §§ 4-153—4-157 and enacted new §§ 4-153—4-157 as set out herein. Former §§ 4-153—4-157 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2005-263, adopted October 11, 2005.  
Sec. 4-154. - Recording. 
If compliance is not had with the order of the building appeals and advisory board within the time specified therein, and no appeal has been properly and timely filed, the building official shall file in the office of the county recorder a certificate describing the property and certifying that the building is a substandard building and that the owner has been so notified. Whenever the corrections ordered shall thereafter have been completed or the building demolished so that it no longer exists as a substandard building on the property described in the certificate, the building official shall file a new certificate with the county recorder certifying that the building has been demolished, or all required corrections have been made so that the building is no longer substandard, whichever is appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-155. - Notice to vacate. 
(a)  Posting. Every notice to vacate shall, in addition to being served as provided in section 4-152(a), be posted at or upon each exit of the building, and shall be in substantially the following form: 
DO NOT ENTER 
UNSAFE TO OCCUPY 
It is a misdemeanor to occupy this building, or to remove or deface this notice. 
Building Official 
City of Cedar Hill 
Sec. 4-155, Cedar Hill Code of Ordinances 
(b)  Compliance. Whenever such notice is posted, the building official shall include a notification in the notice and order issued by him under this subdivision, reciting the emergency and specifying the conditions which necessitate the posting. No person shall remain in or enter any building which has been so posted, except that entry may be made to repair, demolish or remove such building under permit. No person shall remove or deface any such notice after it is posted until the required repairs, demolition or removal have been completed and a certificate of occupancy issued pursuant to the provisions of the building code. Any person violating this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-156. - Repair, vacation and demolition; standards to be followed. 
The following standards shall be followed in the ordering of the repair, vacation or demolition of any substandard building or structure: 
(1)  If any building declared a substandard building under the ordinance shall either be repaired in accordance with the current building code or shall be demolished at the option of the building owner. 
(2)  If the building or structure is in such condition as to make it immediately dangerous to the life, limb, property or safety of the public or of the occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated. 
(Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-157. - Enforcement of the order of the building appeals & advisory board—Compliance. 
(a)  Generally. After any order of the building appeals and advisory board made pursuant to this article shall have become final, no person to whom any such order is directed shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey any such order. Any such person who fails to comply with any such order is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Failure to obey order. If, after any order of the building appeals and advisory board made pursuant of this article has become final, the person to whom such order is directed shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey such order, the building official may cause such person to be prosecuted under subsection (a) of this section or institute any appropriate action to abate such building as a public nuisance. 
(c)  Failure to commence work. Whenever the required repair or demolition is not commenced within thirty (30) days after any final notice and order issued under this article becomes effective: 
(1)  The building official shall cause the building described in such notice and order to be vacated by posting at each entrance thereto a notice reading: 
SUBSTANDARD BUILDING 
DO NOT OCCUPY 
It is a misdemeanor to occupy this building or to remove or deface this notice. 
Building Official 
City of Cedar Hill 
(2)  No person shall occupy any building which has been posted as specified in this subsection. No person shall remove or deface any such notice so posted until the repairs, demolition or removal ordered by the building official have been completed and a certificate of occupancy issued pursuant to the provisions of the building code. 
(3)  The building official may, in addition to any other remedy provided in this section, cause the building to be repaired to the extent necessary to correct the conditions which render the building substandard as set forth in the notice and order; or, if the notice and order required demolition, to cause the building to be demolished, and the materials, rubble and debris therefrom removed and the lot cleaned. Any such repair or demolition work shall be accomplished and the costs paid and recovered in the manner provided in section 4-159. Any surplus realized from the sale of any such building, of from the demolition thereof, over and above the cost of demolition and of cleaning the lot shall be paid over to the persons lawfully entitled thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-158. - Interference with repair or demolition work. 
No person shall obstruct, impede or interfere with any officer, employee, contractor or authorized representative of the city, or with any person who owns or holds any estate or interest in any building which has been ordered repaired, vacated or demolished under the provisions of this article, or with any person to whom such building has been lawfully sold pursuant to the provisions of this article, whenever such officer, employee, contractor or authorized representative of the city, person having an interest or estate in such building or structure, or purchaser is engaged in the work of repairing, vacating and repairing, or demolishing any such building pursuant to the provisions of this article, or in performing any necessary act preliminary to or incidental to such work or authorized or directed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 39, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-159. - Recovery of cost of repair or demolition. 
(a)  All costs for the taking down and removal and/or restoring of such substandard building or structures, including costs for mailing of notice, and/or publication, filing of a statement with the county clerk, bid procedures costs, and/or interest shall be levied, assessed and collected against such property upon which such building is located. If there are any obstructions or other difficulties encountered in the taking down and removal and/or restoring, if required by this division, of such building or structure, such additional costs shall be levied, assessed and collected against such property and/or shall also become a personal obligation to the owners of such property upon which such building is located. 
(b)  The cost provided in this section shall be levied, assessed and collected by the city. If any owner of such property shall fail to pay the costs so assessed within thirty (30) days after being notified of such costs, the city shall file, with the county clerk, a statement of such costs. 
(c)  The city shall have a privileged lien on the premises and/or the personal obligation of the owners of such property, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements to receive the costs so made. For any such costs and interest, suit may be instituted and foreclosure had in the name of the city, and the statement, or a certified copy of the statement shall be prima facie proof of the costs expended in such work or improvements. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 40, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-160. - Waiver of cost. 
The owner of such property may appeal to city council for a waiver of all or part of the cost incurred by the city in the taking down and removal or restoration of a substandard building. The city council may waive any or all costs when sufficient evidence is submitted by an owner showing that payment of such costs would create a hardship. All appeals to the city council for waiver of costs or assessments shall be made in writing on forms provided by the building official, and the hearing shall be held only after publication of the hearing in the official newspaper of the city. The publication shall appear in the official newspaper a minimum of ten (10) days prior to the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 41, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 4-160.1. - Appeals. 
(a)  The owner, lienholder or mortgagee or the city administration may appeal any decision or order of the building appeals and advisory board to state district court within thirty (30) days from the date the order is mailed to the owner, lienholder or mortgagee. 
(b)  Enforcement of any notice and order of the building appeals and advisory board issued under this article shall be stayed during the pendency of an appeal therefrom which is properly and timely filed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 42, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
Sec. 4-160.2. - Enforcement and penalty clause. 
(a)  A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). However, a fine for the violation of a provision of this chapter that governs fire safety, zoning, or public health and sanitation, including dumping or refuse, may not exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(b)  Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter continues shall constitute a separate offense. Each structure or ground which is in violation of any part of this chapter is a separate offense. Each violation in any structure or ground is a separate offense. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall preclude the city's pursuit of any and all other remedies allowed under the civil and criminal statutes, and in equity, to address conditions which are treated in this article, under the theory of public nuisance and abatement of dangerous structures or buildings. Neither shall the city be required, nor prohibited, to issue criminal citations before, after, or during any proceeding prescribed in this article. Specifically, in addition to provisions of this article and remedies afforded under the Texas Local Government Code, Chapter 214, Municipal Regulation of Structures, the city further asserts full authority to exercise its right to remedy under all provisions of the Texas Local Government Code, including, but not limited to, chapter 54, subchapter B, Municipal Health and Safety Ordinances, in prosecution of civil suits for enforcement, injunctive relief, and civil penalties to remedy conditions of public concern described in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-263, § 44, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 2016-588, § 1, 8-9-16)  
ARTICLE IX. - MOVING AND DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Dangerous buildings code; housing code, § 4-136 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4-161. - Mover's license required; bond. 
No person shall move or cause to be moved over or along any street or highway within the city any house or other building unless such person is duly qualified to engage in such occupation and shall obtain a license therefor. Such license shall not be granted until such person applying for same shall first file with the city secretary a good and sufficient bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) payable to the city, such bond to be made by an approved bonding or surety company doing business in the state, conditioned, among other things, that such bonding party will pay any and all damages to any tree, pavement, sewer line, water main, sidewalk, awning, wire, traffic signal, fire alarm, telegraph, telephone, streetlight, power, or other pole provided such awning, wires, or poles are in place according to the ordinances governing the same, or to any other thing injured or damaged by such person, whether such injury or damage shall be inflicted by the party or his agents, employees, or workmen, and conditioned also that the party will save and indemnify and keep harmless the city against all liabilities, judgments, costs, and expenses which may in any way accrue against the city in consequence of the granting of such license and will in all things strictly comply with the conditions of his permit. Upon the execution of the bond and its approval by the city attorney, a license may be issued to the person applying therefor by the city tax assessor and collector. 
(Code 1976, § 4-32)  
Sec. 4-162. - Moving of houses and buildings restricted. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Historical significance is defined as having one (1) or more of the following characteristics: 
a.  Distinctive in character, interest or value and exemplifies cultural, economic, social, ethnic or historical heritage. 
b.  Is an important example of a particular architectural type or specimen or embodies elements of architectural design, detail, material or craftsmanship. 
c.  Has been identified as the work of an important architect or master builder. 
d.  Has been identified with a person or persons who significantly contributed to culture and development. 
e.  Bears a significant relationship to other distinctive buildings, structures, sites, objects or areas. 
f.  Possesses significant archeological value, which has produced or is likely to produce data affecting theories of historic or prehistoric interest. 
g.  Has been identified with a historic event. 
h.  Is designated on the local registry, as a Recorded Texas Historic Landmark, State Antiquities Landmark or an American Civil Engineering Landmark, or is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. 
(2)  Board shall refer to the historic downtown advisory board. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move or cause to be moved a previously occupied house or building from one (1) location outside the city to a location within the city, or to move a previously occupied house or building from within the city to another location within the city for the purpose of residential occupancy, except for houses or buildings that meet the following criteria: 
(1)  The house or building is being moved into or within the old town zoning district; and 
(2)  The board has determined that the house or building is of historical significance. If the board determines that the house or building is not of historical significance, then the property owner may appeal the board's decision to city council. The written appeal shall be filed with the building official within ten (10) days after the board's decision. 
(c)  This section shall not be interpreted to preclude the moving of a previously occupied house or building from one (1) location outside the city to a location within the city, or to move a previously occupied house or building from within the city to another location within the city for the purpose of non-residential occupancy if it has met the same criteria for moving houses and buildings for residential occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 83-672, § 1, 8-9-83; Ord. No. 2019-661, § 1, 1-22-19)  
Sec. 4-163. - Moving bond. 
(a)  Any person who moves a house out of the city, or through or across the city, is required to post a bond with the office of the city secretary as a guarantee or conditioned that any streets or property damaged within the city will be returned to such condition as to meet city requirements within a period of ninety (90) days from the date of such moving of such house off of such property or through the city. The amount of such bond shall be a minimum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or an amount to be determined by the city manager as authorized by the city council after an inspection has been made of the building in question, before it is moved through or out of the city. 
(b)  If within the ninety-day period after the building has been moved it shall appear to the governing body of the city that any damage has been done to the streets, wires, trees or any other public or private property, the governing body shall assess the amount of such damage in favor of the city or the owner of such damaged property. The bond posted for the moving of such building shall then be forfeited in the discretion of the council. 
(Ord. No. 83-672, §§ 5, 6, 8-9-83)  
Sec. 4-164. - Demolition of buildings restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to raze, wreck or dismantle any house or building, the value of which exceeds one hundred dollars ($100.00) within the city without securing a permit therefor as herein provided and removing all materials from the premises and from the public thoroughfares. 
(b)  The city secretary shall issue a permit upon the payment of the fee prescribed in the established building permit fee schedule for demolition of structures within the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-672, §§ 3, 4, 8-9-83)  
Sec. 4-165. - Permit—Required; application; etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to move or cause to be moved a house or building from within the city to a point outside the city or to move a house or building through or across the city, without giving the city secretary notice of such intent ten (10) days prior to such move, obtaining approval at a regular meeting of the city council and securing a permit therefor as herein provided. The permit shall be obtained in the following manner: 
(1)  Application shall first be made to the city secretary who shall be furnished full information as to the then location of the house or building or structure to be moved and the location to which it is desired to be moved. 
(2)  The application shall further be accompanied by a statement by the house mover of all obstructions that will be along the route that will in any way interfere with the moving of the house. This includes, but is not limited to, all bridges, culverts, telephone poles, wires, trees, shrubbery, light poles, signs, awnings or any other obstruction along the route. 
(3)  A map showing the route to be taken by the house mover shall accompany the application. The application shall further state the route desired to be traveled by the house mover, but this route must be approved by the city manager. The city manager shall have the right to change the route or to give a different route. Final approval of the route shall be within the sole discretion of the city council, which shall have the right and authority to require such conditions of moving, including the hours when moving will be permitted, number of policemen required to ensure protection of the public, and emergency traffic measures to be taken, as it deems necessary for the public convenience and safety. 
(4)  The application shall further state the date when the removal is to be commenced, probable time for completion, the total length, width, and height of the structure when mounted to be moved. 
(5)  The application shall also be accompanied with a detailed set of plans and drawings showing all construction and any structural alterations or additions to be made on the house after it has been moved into the city, if allowed by the city council; provided, however, that the building inspector may require other material to accompany the application which may be reasonably necessary for him to decide whether or not a building permit can be issued on such house or structure on which the application is based. Before any house-moving permit may be issued, the person so desiring to move the house shall obtain a building permit if the structure is to be moved from outside the city to within the city or from one (1) place in the city to another place in the city. If the house, building, or structure is to be moved outside the city limits, no building permit shall be required. 
(6)  At the time application is made to the city secretary for a permit to move any house, building, or structure as provided for in this article, the person making such application shall present a written clearance to the city manager from each of the utility companies, and any other person owning or having any overhead wires or cables which cross any street, alley, or other public way in the city along the route the house, building, or structure is to be moved. Such clearance shall approve the route over which the house, building, or structure is to be moved, and the written clearance shall also indicate that satisfactory arrangements have been made with the companies, firms, or corporations for the payment of the services of the company in the cutting or lifting of wires, removing cables, and raising cables, and for the removal of poles or other structures of the companies. No wire or cable shall be touched by any person other than an employee or designated representative of the firm or utility owning the wire or cable. 
(Code 1976, § 4-32; Ord. No. 83-672, § 2, 8-9-93) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 10.  
Sec. 4-166. - Same—Building inspector to examine application and report. 
Upon presentation of a proper application for a building-moving permit to the city secretary, the building inspector or his assistant shall examine the property to be moved, the location where the building or other structure is to be placed, and the proposed route of moving; and if he determines that such building or structure can be moved along the proposed route to the proposed location without undue damage to the streets, alleys, or other public property, and the moving of such building or other structure along such proposed route could be accomplished without danger or hazard to public or private property or to the public generally and would not cause or lead to undue or continued congestion of traffic, and if he further determines that the movement of such structure can be made in compliance with all ordinances of the city and statutes of the state and that a building permit can be issued on the property and that after moving the house or structure within the city it would comply with all ordinances of the city, then he shall report his findings in writing to the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 4-33)  
Sec. 4-167. - Same—Application filing period. 
(a)  The application for a permit required by this article, with all supporting papers required by this article, shall be filed with the city manager not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date it is desired to move such building or other structure; and no permit herein provided for shall be issued until the end of the fifteen-day period after the filing of such application; provided, however, that the city manager shall forward the application to the city council along with the recommendations of the building inspector and city manager. These recommendations shall be in writing stating the findings made by the city manager and building inspector and their reasons for recommending either approval or disapproval of a permit to move such house or other structure. The city council shall then consider the application and recommendations, and may either approve the application to move such house or structure, deny such application, or postpone taking any action on the application for a period of not more than thirty (30) days from the date upon which application was filed with the city manager. If at the end of this thirty-day period the city council has taken no action, the application shall be deemed denied, and shall be void and of no effect. 
(b)  Where the house, building, or other structure sought to be moved is to be relocated within the city limits, the city council, before approving the application and recommendations, shall hold a public hearing. Notice of such hearing shall be given by posting same in the city hall, stating the time and place of the hearing, which time shall be not earlier than ten (10) days from the date of posting. At least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing, the city secretary shall mail notification of the hearing to all owners of property adjacent to the site of the proposed relocation, as well as to all owners of property within two hundred (200) feet from the street frontage of the site of the proposed relocation (including the owners of property on the opposite side of the street within two hundred (200) feet). 
(Code 1976, § 4-34) 
Cross reference— Building inspector generally, § 4-41 et seq.  
Sec. 4-168. - Same—Not to be issued when there are delinquent taxes; fee; notification of utilities. 
(a)  After the application for a permit required by this article has been approved by the city council, the person desiring to move a house, shall take the application to the tax assessor and collector of the city, who shall first check and see if there are any delinquent taxes due or owing against the property for which application is made to be removed; and if there are any delinquent taxes, the tax assessor and collector shall not issue the permit until all taxes have been paid on the property for which application is made. After the property has been checked and the tax assessor is satisfied as to the taxes on such property, then he shall issue the house-moving permit. The tax assessor and collector of the city shall charge and collect before the issuing of such permit for the moving of any house, building, or structure, a fee in such amount as established by the city council from time to time. 
(b)  The person to whom a permit is issued shall immediately notify the chief of the fire department and any and all companies maintaining any electric or telephone wires across or along any street or streets included in the designated route along which such building or other structure is to be moved, of the issuance of such permit, and shall state when same is to be moved and probable length of time necessary for such removal, and in addition, shall notify all gas, water, electric, and telephone companies maintaining service wires or lines to the building or other structure proposed to be moved, of the issuance of such permit and the time that it is proposed to move such building or other structure in ample time to allow the disconnection of such utility service lines to such building or other structure. 
(Code 1976, § 4-35)  
Sec. 4-169. - Removal of wires, cables, etc. 
A person, after receiving a permit to move a house, building, or structure, and after having obtained written clearance from the utility companies, and any other person owning or having overhead wires and cables across any street, alley, or public way in the city, along the route of which the house, building, or structure will pass, shall give twenty-four (24) hours' notice to the companies, not including Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, for such persons to cut any wires necessary to be cut, for the lifting of wires necessary, removing cables, and the removal of poles or structures along the route. After such notification has been received, it shall be the duty of such person to furnish agents or employees, whose duties it shall be to cut and repair such wires of the particular person by whom they are employed, with which the house or structure being moved may come in contact and which it shall be necessary to cut, raise, or remove, in order to permit the house, building, or structure to be moved along the streets, alleys, or other public property of the city. No such person shall furnish any agents or employees in excess of those actually required to do the particular job necessary or to charge any unreasonable rates for such services rendered. 
(Code 1976, § 4-36)  
Sec. 4-170. - Crossing intersections with traffic signals. 
No person while engaged in the moving of a building or structure within the city shall enter or cross any intersection containing an overhead traffic signal unless it is done in the presence of an employee or designated representative of the city building inspector. A charge of five dollars ($5.00) per hour will be made by the city for each man for time spent for the benefit of the mover. An additional charge of three dollars ($3.00) per hour will be made for each additional man needed. Policemen required for moving of the structure shall be arranged for by the person engaged in such moving operations, and shall be employed at the sole expense of such person. 
(Code 1976, § 4-37) 
Cross reference— Traffic-control signs, signals and devices, § 11-141 et seq.  
Sec. 4-171. - Damage to property prohibited. 
All house movers and other persons engaged in the moving of a house or other structure shall proceed in a careful manner in accordance with the terms of the permit granted therefor and at and within the time set therefor in such permit, and shall not in any manner injure or destroy trees, grass plots, curbing, or sidewalks, or in any manner interfere with the property of individuals; and no person, while engaged in the moving of any building or other structure, shall damage, injure, or destroy any public or private property, including trees, shrubs, and grass plots, without the consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 4-39)  
Sec. 4-172. - Leaving building overnight. 
Whenever, in the moving of any house, structure, or building, it shall become necessary that the house, structure, or building remain overnight en route, it shall be the duty of the person, moving same to set proper barricades and warning lights at each street intersection nearest both sides of the house and to keep same properly lighted throughout the night or nights together with warning lights on all sides of the house, building, or structure. Any such house, structure, or building shall at no time be left overnight on any state or federal highway. Location of the site of any such stop shall have the prior approval of the city building inspector before such stop is made. 
(Code 1976, § 4-40)  
Sec. 4-173. - Rules relating to moving. 
The following rules and regulations pertaining to the proposed movement routes and hours for moving shall be strictly observed: 
(1)  On state highways: 
a.  No structure exceeding twenty-five (25) feet in width shall be moved along any state highway passing within the city, except structures in excess of twenty-five (25) feet may be granted permits after such measures have been taken to provide for the public safety as deemed necessary by the city manager and provided prior written approval has been obtained from the state highway department, and such movement shall be made only between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:30 a.m. 
b.  No structure shall be moved along any state highway passing within the city between the hours of 6:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m., 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., or 4:00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. 
(2)  On thoroughfares other than state highways: 
a.  No structure shall be moved along any thoroughfare of the city during the hours of 6:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m., 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., or 4:00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. 
b.  No building or structure shall be moved at any time on Saturdays. 
c.  On thoroughfares forty-four (44) feet or more in width, no structure in excess of twenty-five (25) feet in width shall be moved except during the hours of 12:00 midnight to 5:30 a.m. 
d.  On thoroughfares less than forty-four (44) feet in width, no structure in excess of twenty (20) feet in width shall be moved except during the hours of 12:00 midnight to 5:30 a.m. 
(3)  On all other streets: No structure shall be moved along any street within the city where the width of the structure exceeds the curb-to-curb width of the street. 
(4)  Central business district: No structure shall be moved in or along the city's fire limits except between the hours of 12:00 midnight to 6:00 a.m. 
(5)  Extreme height of mounted structures: No building, structure, or part thereof, shall be moved along any street, alley, or highway within the city if the extreme height of such building, structure, or part thereof shall, when mounted, exceed the height of twenty-five (25) feet from the surface of the street, alley, or highway along which such structure is to be moved. 
(6)  Waiver of height and width restrictions: The city manager shall have the sole discretion to waive restrictions as to the height and width of the building or other structure being removed if and when there are no trees or structures along or overhanging the route along which such building or other structure is to be moved. 
(Code 1976, § 4-41)  
Sec. 4-174. - Building remaining on street after expiration of permit, etc. 
If any house, building, or structure being moved remains on the streets or other property of the city after the expiration of the permit to move such house or building, the person moving the house, building, or structure shall pay to the city the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each day or fraction of a day that such house or building is left on the streets or other property of the city after the expiration of the moving permit. 
(Code 1976, § 4-42)  
Sec. 4-175. - Penalties. 
(a)  Generally. Any person who shall own, move, or assist in moving upon, along, or across any street, avenue, alley, public ground, lot, or open space in the city, any house, structure, or other building, without first obtaining a permit to do so as required hereby, or without complying with the terms and conditions of this article and the terms and conditions of the permit granted, or who, having begun the moving of any house, structure, or building under a permit, shall fail to continue such moving with all reasonable dispatch and speed so as not to unreasonably obstruct any street, avenue, alley, or public ground, or who shall in any other manner violate any of the provisions of this article, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-7 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Failing to cut or repair wires. Any corporation operating or using any line or lines or electric wires along the designated route, which has been notified, or any of its agents, of the intention to move the house, which shall fail to furnish any agent or employee to cut or repair the wires that may be necessary to permit the house to be moved along the designated route, and which shall fail to furnish such agent or employee so as not to delay the work of removing of the house, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-7 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1976, § 4-38)  
Secs. 4-176—4-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 19. 
 
Sec. 4-191. - System established. 
(a)  A system of street numbering is hereby established and a baseline is designated as follows: 
Beltline Road, changing to Mansfield Road, where Beltline Road turns north shall be the baseline for the purpose of building numbering and each street running east and west, or substantially in that course, shall begin for the purpose of such numbering, at the east or west side of Clark Road, or an imaginary line running north and south extended on Clark Road, as the case may be, with the number of one hundred (100) increasing block by block from such initial point to the corporate limits, as it now exists, or may hereafter be extended; and each street running north and south or substantially with that course shall begin at the north or south side of Beltline Road as the case may be, with the number of one hundred (100) increasing block by block from such initial point to the corporate limits, as they now exist, or may hereafter be extended. 
(b)  Addresses shall be issued so that odd numbers shall appear on the north and west side of the street. Even numbers shall appear on the south and east side of the street. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 1, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-192. - Official numbering plan must be followed. 
(a)  Buildings must be numbered in compliance with this article and in accordance with the plan delineating and prescribing the method of numbering buildings which is on file in the office of the building official. 
(b)  The building official shall designate the official number which is to be placed on each building. (A person may request an official number designation by submitting a legal description of the property to the building official.) 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 2, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-193. - Specifications. 
(a)  The official number required by this article shall be of a durable material which will not tarnish, fade, corrode or peel on account of the action of the elements and shall be of a color contrasting to its background. 
(b)  Numbering shall be a minimum of three (3) inches in height and visible from the public street, alleyway, and/or access. Buildings not visible from the street shall also be numbered and visible at the street entrance(s) to the property. Nothing herein shall prohibit any number from being printed by any person when such character of material used will, in the judgment of the building inspector, be equal in strength, durability, and service to the specifications required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 3, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-194. - Placement by owner. 
(a)  Each owner, agent of the owner, or the occupant of any building situated in the city shall display or permit to be displayed, in a conspicuous place, an official building number so that it may be plainly visible from both the front and rear of such building or dwelling. 
(b)  Buildings and dwellings with accessible alleyways are required to place numbers on the rear of their premises. 
(c)  Numbers printed on the curb shall not meet the requirements of this section. 
(d)  The number must be placed prior to completion of the new building or, in the case of commercial, a change of tenant. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 4, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-195. - Basic units of space for numbering. 
The basic unit of space for numbering along public streets and public accesses is twenty-five (25) feet; however, in shopping centers, townhouse areas, apartment areas, and other building complexes where the building official determines that the twenty-five-foot unit is not adequate, he may assign a basic unit of ten (10) feet. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 5, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-196. - Numbering within building complexes. 
(a)  A building complex composed of multiple structures must have an official number assigned to each building. Each unit within each building must also be assigned an official number. If there is sufficient street frontage, each unit or building may be assigned an official street address number. The official number must be prominently posted on the building so that it is visible, where possible, from the nearest vehicular access. The official number for each unit must be conspicuously posted on the unit. 
(b)  If a building is situated within a complex in such a way that it is not visible from a vehicular access, the owner shall post and maintain directional signs along the nearest vehicular access indicating the location of the building by number and unit numbers. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 6, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-197. - Directional signs within building complexes. 
(a)  In a building complex composed of multiple structures which contains internal vehicular accesses, if each official building number is not discernible from the public street, the owner of the building complex shall post directional signs at each entrance to the complex and at each intersection of vehicular accesses, other than public streets. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, an "entrance" to a complex is a point at which vehicular access to the complex, other than a public street, intersects with a public street. 
(c)  The directional signs must indicate the direction to buildings and units by number, must be legible from the vehicular access, and must be painted with a color which is in contrast to the background. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 7, 5-27-86)  
Sec. 4-198. - Diagram of mall areas. 
The owners of a building complex which contains a mall area shall submit to the police and fire departments a diagram of the complex, indicating the location of each business. When a change in business location or tenants is made, the owner shall advise the police and fire departments in writing of the change. 
(Ord. No. 86-850, § 8, 5-27-86)  
Secs. 4-199—4-215. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - SATELLITE DISH ANTENNAE 
 
Sec. 4-216. - Installation, etc., permit—Required. 
No parabolic or dish-type antennae shall be erected, constructed, altered or maintained on any lot within the city without first obtaining from the city a permit for the installation of same. 
(Ord. No. 85-763, § 1, 3-12-85) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 10.  
Sec. 4-217. - Same—Application, fee. 
Any person desiring to place parabolic or dish-type antennae on property within the corporate limits of the city shall first obtain a permit from the city by applying to the city manager or his designee, providing plans for the installation of such parabolic or dish-type antennae and complying with the requirements set forth in this article concerning number and placement of such antennae. The fee for such permit shall be such sum as established by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 85-763, § 3, 3-12-85)  
Sec. 4-218. - Number and placement. 
All parabolic or dish-type antennae located outside of a building shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The maximum number of antennae per residential lot shall be one (1). 
(2)  All setback requirements for property lines provided in all applicable city ordinances shall be observed and compliance therewith shall be required. 
(3)  No antennae may be located in a front or side yard. 
(4)  No parabolic or dish-type antennae shall be roof mounted. 
(Ord. No. 85-763, § 2, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 85-781, § 1, 4-9-85)  
Sec. 4-219. - Penalty; sanctions. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article or fail to comply therewith shall be deemed to be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction in the municipal court, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-7 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Any violation of this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance. In addition to any other relief provided by this article, the city attorney or anyone acting on his own behalf may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation of this article. Such application for relief may include seeking a temporary restraining order, temporary injunction and permanent injunction. 
(Ord. No. 85-763, §§ 4, 5, 3-12-85)  
Secs. 4-220—4-235. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - SIGNS[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-514, § 1, adopted August 27, 2013, repealed the former Art. XII., §§ 4-236—4-248, 4-261—4-265, 4-268 and enacted a new Art. XII as set out herein. The former Art. XII pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-236. - Definitions. 
As used in this article: 
Attached sign shall mean any sign attached to, applied to, applied on or supported by any part of a building (such as a wall, roof, window, canopy, awning, arcade or marquee) which encloses or covers usable space. 
Awning shall mean a shelter supported entirely from the exterior wall of a building. 
Awning sign shall mean a sign whose message is directly applied to an awning of a building. 
Banner signs (temporary) shall mean possessing characters, letters, illustrations, or ornamentation; applied to non-rigid light weight fabric or similar material; intended to be hung without frames. 
Billboard is a sign which promotes or advertises commodities or services available at a location other than where the sign is located and shall include those signs whose message space is available for lease, rent or hire. 
Canopy shall mean a roof-like structure designed to provide protection for objects, pedestrians and vehicles. 
Canopy sign shall mean a sign mounted on or attached to a canopy. 
Changeable electronic variable message sign (CEVMS) shall mean a sign which permits light to be turned on or off intermittently or which is operated in a way whereby light is turned on or off intermittently, including any illuminated sign on which illumination is not kept stationary or constant in intensity and color at all times when such sign is in use, including an LED (light emitting diode) or digital sign, and which varies in intensity or color. A CEVMS sign does not include a sign located within the right-of-way that functions as a traffic control device and that is described and identified in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) approved by the Federal Highway Administrator as the National Standard. 
Commercial sign shall mean any sign containing or conveying a commercial message. 
Commercial message shall mean wording on any sign, logo, or other representation that, directly or indirectly, names, advertises or calls attention to business, product, service, or other commercial activity. 
Conforming sign shall mean a sign which is lawfully in place and which complies with all lawful regulations. 
Construction sign shall mean any temporary sign identifying the property owner, architect, contractor, engineer, landscape architect, decorator or mortgagee engaged in the construction or improvement of the premises on which the sign is located. 
Controlled sign shall mean any sign which is visible from and intended to be seen by travelers on any public roads. 
Decorative flag shall mean a flag or banner that contains no name, initials, logos, insignia or similar items and is used primarily to attract attention or convey a message. 
Development sign shall mean any temporary, on-site promotional sign pertaining to the development of land. 
Directional sign shall mean any onsite sign to direct the public to entrances, exits, and services relating to the property. 
Directory sign shall mean any sign listing occupants within shopping centers, industrial sites, retail districts, office districts, and commercial sites. 
Façade shall mean any separate face of a building, including parapet walls and omitted wall lines, or any part of a building oriented in the same direction, or in directions within forty-five (45) degrees of one another, which are to be considered as part of a single façade. 
Face shall mean the surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the message is displayed or illustrated, not including the sign structure or frame. 
Ground sign shall mean any sign which is erected on vertical framework consisting of uprights supported by the ground. 
Illuminated sign shall mean any sign which has characters, letters, figures, or designs illuminated by electric lights, luminous tubes, or other means that are specifically placed to draw attention to, to light up, or to provide nighttime viewing of the subject matter on the sign face. 
Kiosk sign shall mean a free-standing structure, owned or leased and controlled by or on behalf of the city, located in city rights-of-way, featuring a City of Cedar Hill identification panel at the top of each structure, for the city's use in displaying directional information to new homes, developments, municipal or community events or facilities, emergency services, businesses, churches and other non-commercial establishments and locations lawfully operating with a certificate of occupancy within the city limits of the City of Cedar Hill. Kiosk signs are subject to the provisions of section 4-246 of this chapter. 
Logo shall mean a design or insignia of an organization, individual, company or product which is commonly used in advertising to identify that organization, individual, company or product. 
Multi-tenant sign shall mean any sign that advertises more than one (1) business or occupant. 
Menu board sign shall mean an outside sign utilized by the public patronizing a drive-through business as to bill of fare or other products or services. 
Mural sign shall mean noncommercial pictures, which do not depict advertising, logos, or images of a product or service which is sold on the premises, painted on, or attached to the exterior walls. 
Non-commercial sign shall mean any sign that does not contain or is not used to convey a commercial message. 
Nonconforming sign shall mean any sign which does not now conform to the requirements of the zoning district in which it is located or the zoning chapter standards, but that did meet all requirements prior to adoption or amendment of this article. 
Official sign shall mean a sign erected by public officers or public agencies within their territorial jurisdiction for the purpose of carrying out an official duty or responsibility. 
On-site sign shall mean any sign identifying or advertising a business, person, organization or activity installed on the same premises which such business, person, organization or activity is located. Activity includes the manufacture or sale of the products of a business. Any non-commercial signs are deemed "on-site" and are allowed wherever signs are allowed in accordance with provisions of this chapter, the objective criteria set forth in the Tables "Attachment A and Attachment B"* [] which are incorporated herein as if fully set forth and made a part hereof. 
Off-premises sign shall mean any sign, commonly known as a billboard, that advertises a business, person, activity, goods, products or services not located on the premises where the sign is installed and maintained, or that directs persons to a location other than the premises where the sign in installed and maintained. 
Pennant shall mean a device typically made of a lightweight plastic, fabric or other material usually triangular in shape and attached to a single cord. 
Political sign shall mean any temporary sign or advertisement promoting the candidacy of a person running for governmental office or promoting a position on an issue to be voted on at a governmental election. 
Portable and/or display sign shall mean a sign or display surface temporarily fixed to a standardized advertising or structure which can be regularly moved from location at periodic intervals and is not permanently affixed to the real property. 
Premises shall mean for any developed property, an area of real property constituting the lot, parcel or tract of land which encompasses all the buildings, structures, appurtenances and land held under common ownership and devoted to common use, including a shopping center; for any undeveloped property premises shall mean an area of real property constituting a lot, parcel or tract of land. 
Projecting sign shall mean a sign that is attached or affixed perpendicularly or more perpendicularly than parallel to a building wall or structure other than a pole and extends or projects from it more than twelve (12) inches. 
Protective sign means any sign which is commonly associated with safeguarding the permitted uses of the occupancy, including but not limited to, "bad dog", "no trespassing" and "no solicitors". 
Real estate sign shall mean any temporary sign pertaining to the sale or rental of property. 
Residential district shall mean a district zoned for residential use in the City of Cedar Hill Comprehensive Zoning Chapter excluding multi-family. 
Sign area calculation of, shall mean the actual area of the face of the sign, unless the sign is not of a regular (square, rectangle, triangle, and circle) shape. In the case of an irregular-shaped sign, the gross surface area shall be calculated by enclosing the extreme limits of the sign by no more than four (4) rectangles. The sum of these rectangles shall be the gross surface area. However for each rectangle over one (1), the maximum allowed square footage shall be reduced by ten (10) percent. Sign area shall not be less than illuminated area of the sign. 
In the event two (2) or more signs share a single structure, each sign or panel may be considered separately for square footage purposes, except that the combined footage of such signs cannot exceed the total square footage allowed for the sign. 
Sign code application area shall mean the corporate limits of the city and the area of its extraterritorial jurisdiction as defined by V.T.C.A. Local Government Code, § 42.021. 
Vehicle sign shall mean signs mounted on a vehicle, including trailers, normally licensed by the State of Texas. 
Temporary sign shall mean any sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, cardboard, wallboard or other like materials, with or without frames which is not permanently attached to the ground, wall or building, and which is intended to be displayed for a short period of time only. 
Visibility triangle shall mean a triangle sight area, at all intersections, which shall include that portion of public right-of-way and any corner lot within the adjacent curb lines and a diagonal line intersecting such curb lines at points thirty-five (35) feet back from their intersection. 
(Ord. No. 2013-514, § 2, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2014-529, § 1, 1-28-14; Ord. No. 2015-558, § 1, 7-14-15) 
Footnotes:

Sec. 4-237. - Permit—Required. 
Except as provided in sections 4-242 and 4-261 through 4-265 any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation desiring to place, locate, erect, construct, reconstruct, replace, renovate, repair or alter any part of a sign, including the face, supporting structure or other integral part regulated by this division must have obtained a written permit from the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-514, § 2, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 4-238. - Same—Prerequisites for submission. 
Before any permit required by section 4-237 may be submitted for formal issuance, the applicant shall comply with the following requirements, and all items and materials required for submission shall be filed with the building official as prescribed herein: 
(1)  A written application on a form prescribed by the city, which requires the following information: 
a.  Name of applicant. 
b.  Complete address and telephone number of applicant. 
c.  The business or occupation of the applicant, together with the full legal name of the business, the full address and telephone number of the business. 
d.  The street address and legal description of the site of the proposed placement, together with the name, complete address and telephone number of the owner of such site. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit design drawings for approval showing construction details for the sign and sign structure, together with a plot plan showing the placement of the sign on the property or structure. Signs which exceed ten (10) feet in height above the ground shall be certified by a licensed professional engineer. 
(3)  A schematic drawing showing the proposed placement and location of lights or illuminating effects to be placed upon such sign. 
(Ord. No. 2013-514, § 2, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 4-239. - Decision on permit; appeal. 
Within ten (10) days after determining that the application for a sign permit is complete, the building official shall either approve the application or deny the application based upon the objective criteria set forth herein, unless the application is submitted in conjunction with an application for a building permit, in which case the building official must render his decision no later than the date of final action on such permit. In the event the sign permit application is denied, the building official shall specify the section or sections of the sign regulations with which the application is inconsistent. 
The applicant may appeal the denial of a sign permit application by the building official to the sign review board of appeals by filing a written notice of appeal within ten (10) days of the building official's decision. The board shall consider and take action and render a recommendation on the appeal within twenty-one (21) days after the notice of appeal has been filed. The board shall determine whether the decision of the building official shall be reversed, sustained or modified. See section 4-248(4) for exception procedures. 
(Ord. No. 2013-514, § 2, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 4-240. - Non-commercial signs. 
A non-commercial sign shall be authorized in any location that a commercial sign is allowed under this article XII, or as otherwise authorized by law, and shall be located, designed and constructed to the same specifications as such authorized commercial sign. Temporary detached non-commercial signs will be allowed in accordance with Attachment B* []. 
(Ord. No. 2013-514, § 2, 8-27-13)

Sec. 4-241. - Reserved.  
Sec. 4-242. - Certain signs exempted from permit regulation. 
The following signs may be erected or maintained without the issuance of a permit by the city: 
(1)  Signs advertising the sale or lease of property upon which they are located: 
a.  Undeveloped property: Signs of this nature no larger than thirty-two (32) square feet will be allowed for maximum of one (1) year. 
b.  Residential property: Signs pertaining to the sale or rental of property not exceeding eight (8) square feet in area and pertaining only to the property on which they are located and nameplates not exceeding one (1) square foot in area, containing only the name of the occupant of the premises. 
(2)  Signs erected for the protection of life or property including those which provide information about utility lines. 
(3)  Signs that are not visible from public roads or obviously not erected for the purpose of their message being seen from public roads. 
(4)  Official signs. 
(5)  Signs of not more than thirty-two (32) square feet showing the name of a ranch or farm. 
(6)  Directional signs or traffic signs. 
(7)  Political campaign signs. Political campaign signs are not regulated under this chapter and are subject only to the provisions of chapter 4, article XII, division 2 and chapter 19, article VI of this Code of Ordinances. 
(8)  Seasonal decorations and displays during the period beginning November first of each year and ending the first Monday after January first of the next succeeding year. 
(9)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the display of a national flag and/or state flag whose size does not exceed forty (40) square feet and which flag is displayed upon a flagpole which does not exceed thirty (30) feet in height. All national flags or state flags in excess of the foregoing sizes must apply for an exception. 
(10)  Signs in residential housing districts with dimensions less than set forth in Attachment B* [] are exempt from permit. 
(11)  Kiosk signs. 
(12)  Mural signs 
(Ord. No. 2013-514, § 2, 8-27-13; Ord. No. 2014-529, § 1, 1-28-14; Ord. No. 2016-578, § 1, 12-8-15) 
Footnotes:
