ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 89-1017, § 1, adopted Mar. 14, 1989, repealed the former provisions of this chapter pertaining to water and sewers which comprised Arts. I—V, §§ 18-16—18-18, 18-61—18-63, 18-76, 18-91—18-100, 18-121—18-143 and 18-161—18-182. Section 2 of the ordinance adopted similar new provisions to be included as Arts. I—VI, §§ 18.1—18.51. To facilitate codification and reference, such provisions have been included herein as Art. II, Divs. 1—6, §§ 18-16—18-66, at the discretion of the editor. See also the editor's note to Art. III of this chapter. The former water and sewers provisions derived from the following sections of the city's 1976 Code; 15-1—15-11, 15-11.5, 15-12—15-17, 15-17.5, 15-18, 15-18.5, 15-19, 15-20, 15-50.1—15-50.21, 15-50.201—15-50.203, 15-53, 15-61—15-69 and 15-71, as amended. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of amendments. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-16. - Definitions. 
In this article, the following definitions apply: 
Applicant means a person who makes application to receive a service from the department. 
Backflow prevention device means a device including, but not limited to, reduced pressure devices, double-check valves and vacuum breakers approved by the city and used to prevent water of unknown quality in private plumbing facilities from flowing back into the water system. 
Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a wastewater drainage system which receives wastewater from pipes within a building and conveys it to the building lateral which begins two (2) feet outside the inner face of the building wall or foundation. 
Building lateral means the conduit or pipe extending from the building drain to the wastewater service line at the property or other lawful place of disposal. 
Building water line means the water line on private premises which acts as the main water service to the premises. 
Capital recovery fee means a charge or assessment imposed by the city to provide funding or to recoup the costs of general water and wastewater system capital improvements necessitated by and attributed to new growth and development, but not for the costs of on-site or off-site facilities which are the direct responsibility of the developer. 
City plan commission means the city plan and zoning commission. 
Closed sprinkler system means a fire protection system with automatic waterflow sprinklers from which no water may be taken manually except from the test cock. 
Corner lot means a lot which abuts upon not more than one (1) pair of intersecting public streets within a larger platted subdivision. 
Cross connection means any physical connection or arrangement of pipes or devices between two (2) otherwise separate water supply systems, one (1) of which contains potable water and the other water of unknown or questionable quality, whereby water may flow from one (1) system to the other, the direction of flow depending upon pressure differential between the two (2) systems. 
Customer means a person who: 
(1)  Has an account in his name with the department for a service; 
(2)  Has made application for a service, and the service has been provided or made available by the department at the location specified in the application; or 
(3)  Uses, receives or benefits from service, even though no account for service may exist or no application for service may have been made. 
Department means the utilities department of the city. 
Developer means the owner or agent of the owner platting, replatting or otherwise developing lots or tracts of property for further sale, lease, development or redevelopment for residential, commercial or industrial uses. 
Director means the director of the department or his authorized assistants and representatives. 
Fire protection system means any configuration of pipes connected to a sprinkler system or other fire protection device on private premises which, when connected to the water system, is used to extinguish fires. 
General service means service to premises that are not residential service premises. 
Individual owner means an owner requesting extension of an existing water or wastewater main to property which is or will be used in the operation of his own residence or in the operation of a business not requiring larger than one-inch water service connection, which property will not be further sold or leased in connection with its intended function. 
Obstruct means to: 
(1)  Make passage impossible or unreasonably inconvenient or hazardous; or 
(2)  Interfere or cause interference with a specific activity in order to prevent the activity from starting, continuing or concluding. 
Off-site main means a water or wastewater main lying totally outside of the tract of land to be subdivided and developed for resale, lease or further development. 
On-site main means a water or wastewater main which lies within a subdivision or along one (1) or more sides of a subdivision and is intended to primarily serve that subdivision. 
Owner means the legal fee title holder of record of property. 
Oversize main means a main which exceeds the minimum size of main necessary to serve a particular subdivision, as determined by the city manager, in order to allow the main to serve other property as well as the subdivision. 
Permittee means a person granted a permit under this article. 
Premises or property means real property and includes improvements. 
Pro rata means a proportion of the total cost of water or wastewater extensions or replacements necessary to serve an individual owner's property, based upon the total front footage to be served. This proportion represents the charge to the individual owner or the refund for extending or replacing the main, the amount of which charge or refund is provided in this article. 
Residential service means service to premises that are single-family or duplex dwelling units, or other premises containing dwelling units for which each unit is individually metered. 
Satisfactory credit history with the department means that service has not been cut off within the past twelve (12) months for nonpayment of charges, nor has payment for service been delinquent more than once in the past twelve (12) months. 
Service means all service provided for the use and benefit of persons inside and outside the city through the operations and facilities of the department including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Supply of treated water; 
(2)  Wastewater collection, treatment and disposal; 
(3)  Building and extension of service mains; 
(4)  Providing of meters and service connections to property; 
(5)  Discontinuance, restoration or repair of service; 
(6)  Extension or replacement of service mains for which pro rata or other assessments are charged; 
(7)  Collections of rates or fees for service; and 
(8)  Other department activities for the benefit of the general public authorized under this article. 
Service line means the pipe or conduit which extends from the water or wastewater main and which connects with the meter or the building lateral to provide a water or wastewater service connection. 
Side main means a water or wastewater main that lies along one (1) or more sides of a subdivision and is capable of serving property adjacent to or near the subdivision for which the extension was made. 
Standard size wastewater main means a wastewater main not less than eight (8) inches in diameter. 
Standard size water main means: 
(1)  A water main not less than eight (8) inches in diameter but also of a size adequate to meet the hydraulic capacity of the water system; and 
(2)  A short water main as approved by the director which is not less than six (6) inches in diameter, adequately supported by mains not less than eight (8) inches in diameter, but also of a size adequate to meet the hydraulic capacity of the water system. 
Wastewater means water-carried waste. 
Wastewater main means a conduit or pipe of the wastewater system which conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes, or a combination of both, and into which storm surface water, groundwater or unpolluted wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
Wastewater system means all treatment plants, mains, pumps, interceptors, lift stations, connections, meters, sludge storage facilities, appurtenances and other facilities of the city, or facilities located in the city but owned by others, which are employed in the collection, treatment and disposal of wastewater. 
Water main means a conduit or pipe of the water system which conveys water. 
Water system means all treatment plants, mains, pumps, meters, connections, supply reservoirs, storage tanks, appurtenances and other facilities of the city, or facilities located in the city but owned by others, which are employed in the purification, transportation and supply of treated and untreated water. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. I, § 18.1), 3-14-89) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-3.  
Sec. 18-17. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Authority. The city manager is authorized to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Civil jurisdiction. This article may be enforced by civil court action as provided by state and federal law. 
(c)  Offenses. A person who violates the provisions of this article is guilty of a separate offense for each day or portion of a day during which the violation continues. 
(d)  Penalty. Each offense under sections 18-42, 18-47(b), 18-50(b) and 18-56(a)(3) is punishable by a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Every other offense under this article is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(e)  Culpability. A person is criminally responsible for a violation of this article if the person: 
(1)  Commits or assists in the commission of a violation; or 
(2)  Is a customer, owner, tenant, permittee or other person in control of the premises determined to be the source of a violation. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. I, § 18.2), 3-14-89) 
Cross reference— General penalty; continuing violations, § 1-7 et seq.  
DIVISION 2. - APPLICATIONS, DEPOSITS, METERS, COLLECTIONS 
 
Sec. 18-18. - Application for service; contents. 
(a)  Application required. Before any service shall be supplied to any person or any premises by the department, the owner or occupant of the property shall make the proper written application for such services with the department. The application must be made on forms provided by the department. 
(b)  Contents of application. If such application is for service to a residence, the name of the head of the family in control of such premises shall be given, and if the service other than a residence, the name or names of the persons in control of the premises or of the business conducted therein shall be given. All applications for services to office buildings must be signed by the owner or agent. 
(c)  Contract. The application constitutes a contract to pay the city, for the use and benefit of the department, all charges for service including pro rata and capital recovery fee charges and to abide by all provisions of this article, the provisions of this Code and other local, state and federal laws relating to the service. 
(d)  Telephone application. An application for service may be requested by telephone, but for persons of whom a security deposit is required, a written application must also be signed and returned to the city manager within fifteen (15) days after service is initially requested by telephone. The city manager is authorized to provide service in the interim, but if the written application is not signed and returned within the period required, service will be discontinued until the written application is signed and returned. 
(e)  Accurate information. An applicant shall furnish proper identification and correct information when applying for service. If information is not furnished or is false, the application may be denied and service, where provided, may be discontinued. A person commits an offense if he knowingly makes a false statement on an application for service under this article. 
(f)  Use without application. A person who occupies premises and uses service without making application is responsible for all water used from the date of the last meter reading previous to that person occupying the premises. If the person is a tenant and the owner of the premises has failed to give the notice required in section 18-29, then the owner is jointly and severally responsible with the tenant for the charges. 
(g)  Omission of proper information from application. Any consumer who shall discontinue the place of business or move from his residence and leave a bill for water service or any other services due the department, and shall make application for service at some other address, either under his own name or under a different name, without stating to the department the old address and name under which service was received at the address where there is a bill due, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.3), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-19. - Security deposits; exemptions. 
(a)  Form of security. Unless exempted under subsection (f), a security deposit shall be made at the time of application for service by all customers. Residential customers shall be required to make cash security deposits. For nonresidential customers, the security deposit shall be in one (1) of the following forms: 
(1)  Cash; 
(2)  Guaranty bond; 
(3)  Letter of credit drawn on a state or federally chartered lending institution. 
(b)  Amount. The city manager shall establish the amount of a security deposit in accordance with section 18-32. 
(c)  Failure to provide security. The city manager may refuse or discontinue service if a person fails to: 
(1)  Make a required security deposit with his application; or 
(2)  Increase the amount of his security deposit after being notified that an increase is required. 
(d)  Form of noncash security. A customer must submit a noncash security deposit on a form provided or approved by the city manager. 
(e)  Hardship cases. In cases of hardship, the city manager may allow residential service customers to make cash deposits in installments. 
(f)  Exemptions from security deposit requirement. Security deposits will not be required for service to or for the following: 
(1)  City departments; 
(2)  Cedar Hill Independent School District; 
(3)  State of Texas; and 
(4)  Dallas County and Ellis County. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.4), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-20. - Use of security deposits. 
(a)  Accounting requirements. The department shall keep: 
(1)  Accurate records of all security deposits including, but not limited to, the depositor's name, amounts deposited and deposits refunded; and 
(2)  Separate accounts of all security deposits. 
(b)  Administration of deposits. The department shall administer cash security deposits in accordance with the following rules: 
(1)  A deposit will be applied toward payment of the final bill amount due the city when a service account is closed or becomes inactive due to delinquency, transfer of ownership or other reasons. A deposit made to secure service to premises may be transferred to any other premises within the city where service is provided in the depositor's name. 
(2)  A deposit, less amounts due for service, will be returned to the customer when service is discontinued, unless the deposit is transferred to another address at the request of the customer. 
(3)  Deposits may be invested or used for capital improvements, but sufficient cash shall be accounted for and kept on hand to meet the normally anticipated level of refunds. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.5), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-21. - Security deposit refunds. 
(a)  Refund requirements. The department may refund a security deposit to the customer when the customer meets all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The customer has been receiving service for twelve (12) continuous months; 
(2)  The customer has acquired a satisfactory credit history with the department; 
(3)  The customer has not made payment during the past twelve (12) months with a check returned due to insufficient funds; and 
(4)  The customer has no delinquent bills outstanding. 
(b)  Refusal to refund. Notwithstanding subsection (a), the department may refuse to refund a security deposit where the city manager determines from the circumstances of a customer's account that there is a substantial risk of financial loss to the department. Factors the city manager will consider in evaluating the risk include: 
(1)  The usage pattern and payment history of the customer; 
(2)  If the service is to a business or to rental property, the general economic conditions in the city for such a business or property. 
(c)  New security deposit required. The department may require a new security deposit from a customer after a refund has been made to the customer in accordance with the following rules: 
(1)  A new security deposit will be required in the event the customer's credit history is no longer satisfactory; 
(2)  The refund requirements of subsection (a) will apply, except that the period specified in subsections (a)(1) and (2) shall be twenty-four (24) months. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.6), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-22. - Payments of fees for services; delinquency of charges; discontinuance or refusal of service; notice of discontinuance. 
(a)  When charges delinquent, bill items. Except where otherwise provided by written contract between the customer and the city, charges for services furnished become delinquent if payment is not received in the utility billing office at 502 Cedar Street, Cedar Hill, Texas on or before the due date, which is fifteen (15) days after the bill is rendered. After the due date, the customer must pay a delinquent charge of five (5) percent of the unpaid balance, which includes water charges, sewer service, sanitation, sales tax and other related fees. The department shall send a monthly billing indicating: 
(1)  The service date and the due date; 
(2)  The amount due for services rendered (including all previous delinquent charges, if any, still due and owing), if the bill is paid by the due date; and 
(3)  The delinquent charge due if the customer fails to pay the bill by the due date. 
(b)  Authority to waive delinquent charges. The charges for delinquent payment may be waived if the customer can show good cause for the delinquency. The decision to waive the requirements of subsection (a) rests solely with the city manager. 
(c)  Bill not received. Failure to receive a bill from the department does not relieve a customer or other person liable for charges under this article from liability for payment for service. 
(d)  Authority to discontinue service. The city manager may refuse application for service, discontinue service or refuse to restore service to: 
(1)  A customer who fails to pay any charges due under this article within seven (7) days after the sending of notice of discontinuance; 
(2)  A customer who violates any provision of sections 18-24, 18-30 or divisions 3 through 6 of this article or the plumbing code; 
(3)  A person making application for service to property at an address, if the person has delinquent charges outstanding at another address; 
(4)  A customer who fails to pay the required security deposit or who pays said deposit with a check which is returned for insufficient funds; or 
(5)  A customer at any premises if the city manager determines that a substantial waste of water or a health hazard is occurring as a result of leaking, damaged, open or disconnected private laterals, pipes or drains on the premises. 
(e)  Cutting and plugging connections. The city manager's authority to discontinue service includes the right to cut and plug water or wastewater connections to private property. The costs of cutting and plugging connections will be charged to the customer in addition to the delinquent charges due. 
(f)  Restoration of service. Discontinued service will not be restored until the customer, owner or some other person either pays all charges due (including the charges to restore service or connections), makes arrangements for payment satisfactory to the city manager or, where applicable, ceases violation of the particular Code provision in question. The decision to restore service while delinquent charges or Code violations still exist rests solely with the city manager. 
(g)  Notice of discontinuance. The city manager must notify a customer in the following manner before discontinuing service under subsection (d): 
(1)  The city manager or the director must send the customer at least seven (7) days' advance written notice of pending discontinuance. 
(2)  The notice must provide a statement of reasons for cutoff and a statement of delinquent charges due, where applicable. The notice must also provide a time, place and means by which the customer may cure the delinquency or violation or dispute the validity of the reasons for discontinuance. 
(3)  The notice may be served either in person or by mail. 
(4)  Additionally, in cases of master-metered apartments or condominiums, the city manager or the director must cause a notice of pending discontinuance to be posted on the door of each dwelling unit known to be occupied and in a conspicuous place within the property manager's office or the common areas of the premises. 
(h)  Exceptions to notice requirement. Subsection (g) does not apply to discontinuance of service resulting from a violation of this article if the city manager determines that immediate discontinuance is necessary to prevent an imminent threat or occurrence of: 
(1)  Harm to the health or safety of persons; 
(2)  Damage to city or private property; or 
(3)  Contamination of the system. 
(i)  Customer's request to discontinue. Upon a customer's written request, the department may discontinue service to the customer. Upon receipt of the request, the department may remove the water meter and service connections. However, the customer is liable for all charges incurred prior to removal of the meter. Where service is furnished through more than one (1) meter, the customer may request discontinuance of one (1) or more meters and thereafter be billed on the basis of the remaining meter or meters. 
(j)  Cumulative remedies. Enforcement of this section does not waive any additional remedies, civil or criminal, available to the city under law. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.7), 3-14-89; Ord. No. 92-137, § 1, 11-10-92; Ord. No. 2000-51, § 1, 12-12-00)  
Sec. 18-23. - New application for premises with delinquent charges. 
(a)  When new application not accepted. Where service has been discontinued, refused or posted for discontinuance at a premises due to nonpayment of delinquent charges or a violation of this Code, a new application will not be accepted from another person to resume service in the same place, under the same or another name, so long as the previous customer continues to occupy or own the premises as his residence or place of business until: 
(1)  All delinquent charges are paid; 
(2)  Arrangements for payment satisfactory to the city manager are made; or 
(3)  The violation is abated. 
(b)  Avoidance. This section also applies to premises where service is furnished to a tenant and the premises are transferred to a person after notice of discontinuance for the purpose of avoiding payment of charges or avoiding enforcement of this section. 
(c)  Service to a tenant. If services are furnished by the customer or anyone to a tenant, it shall be considered additional service to the customer or applicant; the provisions of this article apply in the same manner as if the service were provided solely to the customer or applicant. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.8), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-24. - Meters required; meters to be read monthly; estimated charge; water leakage. 
(a)  Meters generally. Unless otherwise provided in this article, a customer shall receive water service only when measured through a meter. All water meters furnished by the department shall at all times remain the property of the city. The director shall determine the size, type, quantity and location of meters and connections to meters to be installed. Each meter shall be read, when possible, once a month and a bill rendered accordingly. 
(b)  Estimated bill, circumstances. The quantity of water delivered to a premises will be estimated under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The meter reader is unable to procure a reading of the meter because access to the meter is obstructed or made hazardous by an animal or otherwise; 
(2)  The meter does not properly function or the equipment used to read the meter does not properly function; 
(3)  Adverse weather or an act of God prevents the reading of the meter; 
(4)  No meter is in place at the premises; 
(5)  For some other reason, a meter reading is not available to the billing section of the department at the time of preparing a bill to the customer. 
(c)  Basis for estimates. An estimate shall be based on past consumption experience at the premises adjusted for seasonal variations, or if there is no past experience, then upon consumption of the same class of customers under similar conditions. If a customer demonstrates to the satisfaction of the city manager that an estimated bill is excessive, then the department shall render a bill based on a revised estimate or on an actual meter reading where possible. 
(d)  Meter inspection. When any customer or consumer of water is of the opinion that the meter through which the water is supplied is incorrect for any reason, he may make application to the department to have the meter examined and tested. No charge will be made for the first meter change or meter test requested by a customer at a single service connection within any twelve-month period. For each additional meter change or meter test requested by a customer within a twelve-month period that does not result in a finding that the meter over-registered in excess of one and one-half (1½) percent, the city manager shall charge the customer a fee as provided in section 18-33(a). 
(e)  Meter reading verification. If the customer contends that a discrepancy appears in a bill or meter reading, the director will inspect the meter and verify the reading. Such inspection is free, if the director verifies a gross discrepancy or a customer requests not more than one (1) verification during any six-month period. Otherwise, a charge shall be made in accordance with section 18-33(c). 
(f)  Water leakage. When a customer experiences a substantial increase in his water or wastewater usage from a hidden water leak, the department will adjust the amount up to one-half the total amount of the largest bill in the previous three (3) months. The department will adjust a bill only if a customer presents a plumber's statement or a written statement prepared by the customer which indicates: 
(1)  The water leak was not reasonably detectable from the surface; 
(2)  The leak has been repaired; and 
(3)  The type of repairs made. 
The director may request additional information before determining if a water leak was reasonably detectable based upon the facts presented. A customer may receive only one (1) adjustment during a twelve-month period, unless the city manager determines that extenuating circumstances justify allowing additional adjustments. 
(g)  Pressure test. If a customer is of the opinion that a leak exists on customer premises, the customer may request the director to make an inspection and pressure test for the purpose of determining if a leak exists. Such inspection and pressure check is free, unless the customer requests more than one (1) such inspection or pressure check in any twelve-month period. Otherwise, a charge shall be made in accordance with section 18-33(d). 
(h)  Return of meters. All water meters furnished to customers are the property of the city and will be returned immediately upon request of the director. Failure to return a meter when requested constitutes grounds for discontinuance or refusal of service. 
(i)  Maintenance of meters. The department is responsible for maintenance, inspection and repair of all water meters rendered unserviceable through normal wear and tear. When replacements, repairs or adjustments of any meter are made necessary by any act, neglect or carelessness of the customer, owner or occupant of any premises, any such expense caused to the department shall be charged against and collected from the customer or owner of the premises, and if not paid, service shall be discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.9), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 98-399, adopted Nov. 10, 1998, repealed § 18-25 in its entirety. Formerly, § 18-25 pertained to backflow prevention devices and derived from § 2(Art. II, § 18.10) of Ord. No. 89-1017, adopted March 14, 1989.  
Sec. 18-26. - Joint owners or users; liability for charges; transfer of accounts. 
(a)  Benefits in general. Service is deemed to benefit: 
(1)  The occupants of the premises served; 
(2)  The owners of the premises served; and 
(3)  The property served. 
(b)  Personal liability. The customer in whose name the account for service exists has the primary personal liability for service rendered under this article. Nevertheless, where service is provided to a tenant or occupant in a single-family residence, or to more than one (1) tenant or occupant through a master meter or single service connection, if the customer in whose name the account exists fails, refuses or is unable to pay charges due, the other owners and occupants will remain jointly and severally liable for the unpaid delinquent charges. The city manager may refuse service or discontinue service in the same manner provided for in section 18-22 until all delinquent charges are paid. 
(c)  Transfer of accounts. Where a person liable for delinquent charges at one (1) address is found to have an account in his name at another address, the delinquent amounts due at the previous address may be transferred to the account at the new address and service discontinued at the new address until the delinquent amounts are paid. 
(d)  Charges constitute a lien. When delinquent charges remain unpaid and the procedures of section 18-27 are followed, those delinquent charges shall constitute a lien against the property served. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.11), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-27. - Water lien procedure. 
(a)  Authority. The city is authorized, in accordance with the provisions of article 1175(11) of the Texas Revised Civil Statutes, to perfect the lien upon property which occurs as provided in section 18-26, for the purpose of securing the payment of delinquent charges incurred as a result of service to the property. The lien may include reasonable costs associated with filing the lien and collection of the delinquent charges. 
(b)  Perfected lien. The lien may be perfected only when charges incurred by a customer for service become delinquent and when the city manager determines that other means for fully collecting the delinquency are inadequate or unavailable. 
(c)  Form of the lien. Upon request of the city manager, the form of the lien must be prepared by the city attorney. The form must contain: 
(1)  A statement indicating the purpose of the lien; 
(2)  The address of the property which is the subject of the lien, where the address is ascertainable; 
(3)  A complete legal description of the property which is the subject of the lien; 
(4)  The amount of delinquent charges incurred upon the property as of the date of execution of the lien; and 
(5)  The costs associated with filing the lien and collecting the delinquent charges. 
(d)  Execution and recording. The lien must be: 
(1)  Executed by the city manager and acknowledged by a notary public of the State of Texas; 
(2)  Approved as to form by the city attorney; and 
(3)  Filed in the deed or lien records of the county in which the property is located. 
(e)  Additional charges; correction lien. Should additional delinquent charges be incurred subsequent to the date of the original lien's execution, a correction lien may be executed and filed, in the form provided above, fixing the additional delinquent charges. The correction lien, when filed of record, shall relate back to the date of recording of the original lien and shall become a part of the original lien. 
(f)  Suit to foreclose. The city attorney, at the request of the city manager, shall file suit to judicially foreclose the lien in a state court of competent jurisdiction. The suit may not be filed earlier than sixty (60) days after the recording date of the lien. 
(g)  Release of lien. Upon certification by the city manager that all delinquent charges which existed against the property have been fully paid, the city manager is authorized to execute a release of the lien. The release shall be prepared and approved as to form by the city attorney and shall be duly acknowledged. After execution, the city manager must immediately file the release in the deed or lien records of the county in which the property is located. 
(h)  Cumulative remedies. This section is cumulative of any other remedies, methods of collection or security available to the city manager or the city under the Charter and ordinances of the city or under state law. This section does not affect the city manager's authority to refuse or to furnish service when delinquent charges exist. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.12), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-28. - Notice of water lien. 
(a)  Form of notice. Prior to recording of the water lien, the city manager shall send notice, by certified mail, return receipt requested, that a lien will be fixed on the property in accordance with law. The notice must provide a time, place and means by which the charges causing the lien may be paid. The notice must be sent to: 
(1)  The customer is whose name the account for service to the property exists; and 
(2)  The last-known record owner of the property according to the tax rolls of the city, if the customer is not the owner. 
(b)  Absence of receipt of notice. Absence of receipt of notice does not affect the enforceability of a lien perfected under section 18-27. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.13), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-29. - Notice of vacancy or transfer of property. 
(a)  When notice given. The customer or the owner of property served must notify the department within three (3) calendar days after the occurrence of: 
(1)  Any change in ownership, whether by sale, foreclosure, business reorganization or otherwise; or 
(2)  Any occupancy of previously vacant property; or 
(3)  Any total vacancy in the property served; or 
(4)  Any change of place of residence or business. 
(b)  Failure to notify. Failure to give notice in accordance with subsection (a) shall render the owner and the customer, if he is not the owner, jointly and severally liable for all charges due against the property. Upon receipt of notice under subsections (a)(1) or (a)(3), the city manager shall prepare a final bill for the account. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.14), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-30. - Use of water without permission. 
(a)  Use without consent. A person commits an offense if, where water is furnished to any premises, the person knowingly takes water from any faucet or water connection on the premises without first securing the consent of, and making arrangements with, the owner of the premises or the customer in whose name the account exists. This section does not apply to a person employed by the city who is engaged in work of an emergency nature in his official capacity as a city employee. 
(b)  Use without written application. A person commits an offense if he knowingly diverts or uses water from any part of the water system without making written application and without receiving the city manager's consent to use a service. Absence of an account for service on file with the department constitutes prima facie proof of the lack of the city manager's consent to use a service. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.15), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-31. - City manager's authority to contract; rates as consideration. 
(a)  General contract authority. The city manager is authorized to provide service without the necessity of city council approval except for: 
(1)  A contract for noninterruptable water or wastewater service which is for a fixed term of longer than three (3) years; 
(2)  A contract by which the city receives water or wastewater service; 
(3)  A wholesale service contract involving another utility or governmental entity; and 
(4)  Any service contract otherwise required by state law, city Charter or other provisions of this article to be approved by city council. 
(b)  Consideration. The consideration received by the city for a service contract must be based on the rates prescribed in ordinances enacted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. II, § 18.16), 3-14-89)  
DIVISION 3. - FEES, CHARGES, RATES 
 
Sec. 18-32. - Security deposit amounts. 
(a)  Minimum deposits. The amount of a security deposit shall be determined by the city manager as follows: 
(1)  For residential and business customers with meter size of one (1) inch and below, the standard deposit for a water or sewer account shall be: 
a.  For a 5/8 -inch or ¾-inch meter .....$40.00 
b.  For a 1-inch meter .....50.00 
(2)  For customers with meter size above one (1) inch, an amount is required sufficient to cover two (2) times the average monthly bill in the past twelve (12) months for the location served. If information to determine the total bill for the prior twelve (12) months is unavailable or inapplicable, the deposit shall be two (2) times an average monthly bill estimated by the city manager. 
(b)  Additional deposits. When and if it is found that the deposit required and collected according to the above schedule is not sufficient to cover two (2) times the average monthly bill, the city manager may require an additional deposit. If the city manager determines that there is substantial risk of financial loss; as evidenced by the customer's service being discontinued for nonpayment of charges more than once in any twelve-month period, the city manager may require an additional security deposit not to exceed three (3) times the average monthly bill at the location served. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.17), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-33. - Fees for inspection and testing of meters. 
(a)  Meter inspections. Meter inspections in excess of the number provided free in accordance with section 18-24(d) shall be charged to the customer according to the following schedule: 
(1)  For a 5/8 -inch to ¾-inch meter .....$15.00 
(2)  For a 1-inch meter .....25.00 
(3)  For a 1½-inch meter .....35.00 
(4)  For a 2-inch meter .....50.00 
(5)  For meters larger than 3 inches .....Fee based on actual cost 
(b)  Meter replacement fees. A customer with an existing one-inch service and a five-eighths-inch or three-fourths-inch meter who requests that the meter be increased to one (1) inch shall pay a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Any other customer requesting an increase in meter size, up to but not greater than the size of the existing service, shall pay a connection charge for the requested size meter in accordance with section 18-36(a) and (c). 
(c)  Inspection fee for meter reading verification. Meter reading verifications in excess of the number provided free in accordance with section 18-24(e) shall be charged to the customer for a fee of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) per inspection. 
(d)  Fee for pressure test. Inspections and pressure tests, for purposes of determining if a leak exists on customer premises, in excess of the number provided free in accordance with section 18-24(g) shall be charged to the customer for a fee of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) per inspection or test. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.18), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-34. - Rates for treated water and wastewater service. 
Rates for water and wastewater service shall continue as at present until changed by motion or resolution of the council. The council, by motion or resolution, shall have power to charge water and wastewater rates. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.19), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-35. - Service connection charges. 
(a)  Water service installation and connection charge. The department shall charge for the installation of all water service connections at the following rates: 
(1)  Charges for service installation including the connection of up to fifty (50) feet of service line: 
Connection SizeFee   
¾-inch .....$ 300.00 
1-inch .....480.00 
1½-inch .....780.00 
2-inch .....1,700.00 
(2)  Charges for service installation when water connection exists and the following are: 
Connection Size 	Box Furnished 	Box Not Furnished 
¾-inch 	$108.00 	$150.00 
1-inch 	228.00 	270.00 
1½-inch 	375.00 	500.00 
2-inch 	1,075.00 	1,275.00 
 
(b)  Installation of longer service lines. If any of the service connections in subsection (a) above installed by the department require more than fifty (50) feet of service line, the department shall charge five dollars ($5.00) per linear foot for all service line installed in excess of fifty (50) feet. 
(c)  Installation of large connections. The director will furnish an estimate of cost to an applicant for a service connection larger than two (2) inches in diameter. The charge will be based on material prices and labor costs which prevail at the time the service is required. The applicant must pay the estimated cost before the director will install the connection. 
(d)  Wastewater service installation and connection fees. Except as provided in subsection (e), the city shall charge the following rates for the installation or connection of residential wastewater service lines: 
(1)  For a four-inch sewer tap, a fee of three hundred seventy-five dollars ($375.00) shall be assessed for a normal tap 
(2)  For a six-inch sewer tap, a fee of six hundred twenty-five dollars ($625.00) shall be assessed for a normal tap 
(3)  Street bores for service lines shall be charged twenty dollars ($20.00) per linear foot. 
(e)  Special wastewater connections. The connection charges for the following applications will be based according to material prices and labor rates which prevail at the time the service is requested, as determined by the city manager: 
(1)  The applicant is a commercial or industrial concern; 
(2)  Wastewater service to the premises requires a deep cut connection; 
(3)  The service will be connected to a wastewater main located in an easement; or 
(4)  A customer requests an additional wastewater service line or relocation of an existing wastewater service line. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.20), 3-14-89; Ord. No. 2000-25, § 1, 5-23-00; Ord. No. 2001-68, § 1, 6-12-01)  
Sec. 18-36. - Fees for street cuts. 
In the event any street, highway or roadway must have an open cut for the purpose of performing any of the services hereunder, a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a partial cut or five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a full cut will be charged for the replacement of such open cut by the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.21), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-37. - Charges for use of fire hydrants. 
(a)  A person or business requesting use of water from a fire hydrant pursuant to section 18-50 shall pay a deposit set by the water department based upon cost of backflow assembly testing, assemblage costs, material costs as per market conditions, etc. 
(b)  A person or business using water from a fire hydrant meter will be billed at the volume charge for water service as established by ordinance. 
(c)  Meters not returned to City Hall on the dates required by section 18-50(a)(2)a. shall be assessed a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per day. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.22), 3-14-89; Ord. No. 96-279, § 2, 6-11-96; Ord. No. 99-438, § 2, 7-13-99)  
Sec. 18-38. - Rates for pro rata charges. 
(a)  Standard rate. When a person owning benefited property is charged in accordance with sections 18-57 or 18-58, the following front foot rates will be applied as the pro rata: 
(1)  Seven dollars and seventy-five cents ($7.75) per front foot of the lot or tract of land to which water service connections are made available, where the lot or tract benefits by the enhanced value due to an extension; and 
(2)  Nine dollars and twenty-five cents ($9.25) per front foot of the lot of tract of land to which wastewater service connections are made available, where the lot or tract benefits by the enhanced value due to an extension. 
(b)  Adjustment. The city council may adjust the pro rata rate as prescribed in section 18-58(e). 
(c)  Special rates. The city council may establish special rates and forms of pro rata according to specific circumstances to assure that the pro rata amounts do not exceed the benefits received. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.23), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-39. - Standard cost tables for oversize or off-site facilities. 
(a)  Reimbursement rates, water and wastewater. A standard cost table may be used, when adopted by city council, to calculate refunds for oversize and off-site water and wastewater mains and appurtenances. 
(b)  Costs not in standard cost tables. Reimbursements for costs not included in the standard cost tables in this section will be based on the actual bid price of the installation. The actual reimbursement will be subject to approval by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.24), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-40. - Miscellaneous charges and provisions; rates where no charge specified. 
(a)  Temporary discontinuance charge. The charge for discontinuing service temporarily at the request of the customer or his agent is four dollars ($4.00), except that the city manager may waive this charge where the necessity for turning water off is created by an emergency. 
(b)  Returned check charge. Upon the return of any check to the city for any reason, a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be assessed for each such returned check and shall be paid by the person, firm or corporation presenting such check or by the customer for whom the check was written. 
(c)  Where no charge specified. When charges for a service are not specified in this article, the city manager shall establish charges which are based on the cost of performing the services including, but not limited to, such services as the moving of meter locations, repair to damaged facilities, field location of mains, fire hydrant relocation, installation of traffic lids on meter boxes, replacement of a meter with a meter larger than one (1) inch, water and wastewater main abandonments, installation and removal of temporary service and abandonment of manholes. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. III, § 18.25), 3-14-89)  
DIVISION 4. - WATER AND WASTEWATER 
 
Sec. 18-41. - Control of and access to systems; interference with access generally. 
(a)  Systems as city property. All parts of the water and wastewater systems are the property of the city. The city manager shall maintain and control each system and keep detailed records concerning all aspects of the systems' operations. 
(b)  Access. Only a person who is authorized by the city manager pursuant to section 18-45 will have access to the water and wastewater systems for operation, construction, maintenance, repair and other service-related purposes. 
(c)  Obstruction of authorized persons. A person commits an offense if he knowingly obstructs a person authorized in accordance with section 18-45 from: 
(1)  Gaining access to a part of the water or wastewater systems for purposes of operation, inspection, construction, maintenance or repair; or 
(2)  Performing actual operation, inspection, construction, maintenance or repair of a part of the water or wastewater systems. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.26), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-42. - Emergency authority. 
(a)  Purpose and scope. The purpose of this section is to establish the city's policy in the event of shortages or delivery limitations in the city's water supply. This section applies to: 
(1)  All persons and premises within the city using water from the water system; and 
(2)  All retail customers who live in unincorporated areas within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction and are served by the water system. 
(b)  Emergency water management plan. The city manager shall promulgate and submit an emergency water management plan to the city council for approval, the guidelines of which should include: 
(1)  The conditions under which a particular stage of emergency will be implemented or terminated; and 
(2)  Provisions defining specific events that will trigger an emergency. 
(c)  Authority. The city manager is authorized to implement measures prescribed when required by this section and by the emergency water management plan approved by the city council. The city manager is authorized to enforce the measures implemented and to promulgate regulations, not in conflict with this section or state and federal laws, in aid of enforcement. 
(d)  Implementation of emergency order. The city manager may order that the appropriate stage of emergency response, as detailed in the emergency water management plan, be implemented. To be effective, the order must be: 
(1)  Made by public announcement; and 
(2)  Published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city within twenty-four (24) hours after the public announcement, which order becomes immediately effective upon publication. 
(e)  Duration of order; change; extension. The order can be made effective for up to, but not more than, sixty (60) days from the date of publication. The city manager may upgrade or downgrade the stage of emergency when the conditions triggering that stage occur. Any change in the order must be made in the same manner prescribed in subsection (d) for implementing an emergency order. The city council may, upon the recommendation of the city manager, extend the duration of the emergency order for additional time periods, not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) days each. The city manager shall terminate the order in the manner prescribed in subsection (d) for implementing an emergency order when the city manager determines that the conditions creating the emergency no longer exist. 
(f)  Violation of section. A person commits an offense if he knowingly makes, causes or permits a use of water contrary to the measures implemented by the city manager as prescribed in the emergency water management plan. For purposes of this subsection, it is presumed that a person has knowingly made, caused or permitted a use of water contrary to the measures implemented if the mandatory measures have been formally ordered consistent with the terms of subsection (d), and: 
(1)  The manner of use has been prohibited by the emergency water management plan; or 
(2)  The amount of water used exceeds that allowed by the emergency water management plan. 
(g)  Authority under other laws. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the mayor, the city council or the city manager to seek emergency relief under the provisions of any state or federal disaster relief act. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.27), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-43. - Adequacy of supply. 
(a)  City supply must be adequate. Under no circumstances shall water be furnished by the city to any applicant or customer unless the supply of the city is adequate. In cases of emergency, priority of users of the city's water supply shall be determined by the city manager, subject to the requirements of state law and section 18-42. 
(b)  Revisions. The city council may, from time to time, upon recommendation of the city manager, make revisions in the emergency water management plan approved under section 18-42(b) if prudent conservation requires the revisions. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.28), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-44. - Temporary discontinuance for construction, maintenance or emergency reasons. 
(a)  Reasons for temporary discontinuance. The city manager is authorized to temporarily discontinue service to premises for the following reasons: 
(1)  When a main break or other failure in the water or wastewater systems could injure persons, private or city property, or other parts of the systems; 
(2)  To perform routine maintenance or repair to any part of the water or wastewater systems; 
(3)  To perform emergency maintenance or repair to any part of the water or wastewater systems; 
(4)  In other cases of emergency, when necessary to protect the general health, safety or welfare of persons; or 
(5)  To make a connection to a newly constructed or relocated water or wastewater main. 
(b)  Responsibilities upon temporary discontinuance. In all cases of temporary discontinuance, the city manager must restore service as soon as is practical and must take all reasonable steps necessary to protect the public health and safety under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.29), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-45. - Authorized employees; right of access of employees for inspection and maintenance; access of contractors. 
(a)  Authorized employees. The city manager shall designate those individuals who are employed by the department and authorized to carry a credential of the department. No person other than an authorized employee shall have or use any credential of the department. An employee must surrender credentials to the city manager upon termination of employment or at the request of the city manager. 
(b)  Right to access. An authorized employee shall carry a credential when dealing with the general public. Upon presentation of the credential, an authorized employee shall have free access, at reasonable hours, to private premises receiving service for the purpose of reading or inspecting a water meter, a backflow prevention device or for other service-related activities. Only an authorized employee may have free access to parts of the water and wastewater systems for purposes of operation, construction, repair or maintenance. 
(c)  Access by nonauthorized persons. A person commits an offense if he is not an authorized employee under this section and he knowingly: 
(1)  Uses a department credential to obtain access to private property or to a part of the water or wastewater systems; or 
(2)  Falsely represents, by other than the display of a credential, that he is an authorized employee of the department to obtain access to private property or to a part of the water or wastewater systems. 
(d)  Private contractors. A person performing construction or repair work for the department pursuant to a contract with the city, or an authorized private development contract, has a right of access to those parts of the water or wastewater systems as is reasonably necessary to fulfill performance of the contract; provided that no person shall have the right under this subsection to open or operate any valve in these systems. Access is subject to the express directions of the city manager, the terms of the contract documents and all requirements of this Code concerning permits. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.30), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-46. - Service connections. 
(a)  Maintaining service connections. The department is authorized to maintain service connections from the mains in public rights-of-way to building laterals or building water lines on premises pursuant to the following rules: 
(1)  The city is responsible for maintenance of a service connection from the main to the meter in the case of water service, and from the main to the property line in the case of wastewater service. 
(2)  The city will maintain a service connection at its original size as long as the customer continues use of a service. 
(3)  The city's obligation to continue maintenance of a service connection ceases when the customer abandons use of a service. 
(4)  The city will remove, at the property owner's expense, a service connection made in violation of this Code. 
(5)  The city manager is authorized to charge a fee in accordance with section 18-35 to an applicant or property owner for installation of a service connection. 
(b)  Connection permits. The following rules govern the issuance of a service connection permit: 
(1)  The plumber must submit a copy of the plumbing permit, obtained from the city's building inspection division, with the connection permit application. The connection permit application must specify: 
a.  The address of the work; 
b.  The name of the applicant; 
c.  The name of the property owner; and 
d.  The names of other plumbing subcontractors employed to do the work. 
(2)  The city manager may revoke a permit at any time before work is completed and connection is made if he determines that the terms and conditions of the permit are being violated, and no interested party will have a claim for damages or refunds as a result of revocation. 
(3)  A connection permit must be issued in the name of the applicant and the property owner. A permit is nontransferable and expires six (6) months from the date of issuance. The city will refund permit fees in the event of failure to connect within the term of the permit. 
(4)  The city will refuse to provide service for any person or persons employing a plumber to make any alterations or extensions of the water or wastewater pipes on his premises who shall not first have secured the necessary permit to make such changes. 
(c)  New buildings to be connected with wastewater system. No person, firm or corporation shall construct or erect a new building or buildings for residential, commercial or manufacturing purposes unless such new building or buildings, when completed and prior to occupation, shall tie in to the sewer system of the city and use the same when occupied. This division shall be construed to apply to the construction and erection of a building and buildings on property lying within the jurisdiction of the city, described as lots, tracts or parcels of land lying and being along either or both sides of alleyways, streets or easements wherein there is, at the time of such new construction and erection of a building or buildings hereinabove described, an existing sewer line, branch or lateral of the sewer line in the system in the city and where the new construction is within two hundred (200) feet of the sewer line. 
(d)  Existing buildings to be connected with wastewater system. The following rules apply to existing buildings: 
(1)  Existing businesses shall be required to tie in to the sewer system of the city where a wastewater main is located within two hundred (200) feet of the existing building. 
(2)  When an existing residential dwelling fronts on or has access to a wastewater main which abuts the property in a right-of-way or easement, the owner must either: 
a.  Connect to the wastewater main; or 
b.  Pay the minimum monthly charge for wastewater service for the applicable customer classification. 
(e)  Construction and installation rules. The following rules govern construction and installation of service connections: 
(1)  A building lateral, building water line, drain and other private plumbing must be constructed in strict accordance with the provisions of the city's plumbing and building codes. The city manager may, as a condition of the connection permit, impose additional construction requirements not in conflict with the plumbing and building codes, this article or other applicable state or federal laws and regulations in order to protect the system from damage or contamination, to facilitate connection, or where extraordinary circumstances may require. 
(2)  A building lateral and building water line must be laid up to the property line and the end left exposed. The permittee or his agent shall provide a ditch safe for entry in accordance with state and federal safety standards. A building lateral and building water line must be stubbed out to meet the service line, both as to horizontal location and vertical depth. Location of the service line will be furnished upon request or upon issuance of a connection permit, but the permittee or his agent is responsible for uncovering and confirming the location of the service line before construction of the building lateral or building water line. 
(3)  All service connections must be made only by persons authorized by the city manager, and the private plumbing must meet the construction requirements of the plumbing code. Any ditch dug for the purpose of installing a connection must be backfilled by the permittee or his agent upon completion of the construction. 
(f)  Nuisance. Every commode, wastewater drain, privy or other wastewater receptacle used on premises which is neither connected to the wastewater system nor to a septic tank or receptacle approved under this Code is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a public health hazard. 
(g)  Enforcement authority. The city manager is authorized to promulgate regulations not in conflict with this Code, the city Charter or state laws and regulations to aid in implementing the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.31), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-47. - Cross connections; location of water and sewer mains. 
(a)  Cross connection prohibited. A person shall not make or permit a cross connection between a system of piping supplied by the water system and the following sources of supply, unless properly protected by an approved backflow prevention device: 
(1)  A public or private source of primary supply other than the water system; or 
(2)  Any secondary supply known or suspected to be unsafe for drinking water including, but not limited to, shallow wells, reused industrial supplies, raw surface water or swimming pools. 
(b)  Nuisance. A person commits an offense if he makes or permits a cross connection in violation of subsection (a). The making of a cross connection in violation of subsection (a) is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a public health hazard. 
(c)  Proximity of water and wastewater mains. The city manager shall regulate the relative proximity of water mains to wastewater mains, both existing and under construction, in accordance with the regulations of the city and the Design Criteria for Public Sewerage Systems and the Rules and Regulations for Public Water Supply of the State Department of Health, in order to prevent contamination of the water system. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.32), 3-14-89) 
Cross reference— Control program for cross connections, § 18-220 et seq.  
Sec. 18-48. - Fire protection systems. 
(a)  Application required. A person shall not connect a fire protection system to the water system until application is made to the director and then approved by the director and the fire marshal of the city. 
(b)  General requirements. A fire protection system is subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The fire marshal shall not permit a fire protection system without an approved meter or detector check device with a bypass, except for a closed sprinkler system having an automatic waterflow fire alarm system approved by the fire marshal. 
(2)  A fire protection service line must be no larger than one (1) size smaller than the water main serving the fire protection system, unless the fire marshal approves a size-on-size connection in writing; provided that in every case, the water system must be capable of providing, at the point of delivery, the delivery rate specified by the fire marshal for the customer's fire protection system. 
(3)  A fire protection service line must not be larger than eight (8) inches without the fire marshal's written approval, except a six-inch line supplied in two (2) directions by an eight-inch or larger line may have a six-inch fire service. 
(4)  A fire protection system must conform to the standards and regulations promulgated by the city inspector and other applicable provisions of this Code. 
(c)  Installation of service connections. The city will inspect the installation and perform the maintenance of the necessary meters and service lines connecting the fire protection system to the water system. The cost of installation will be at the sole expense of the customer. 
(d)  Grounds for discontinuance. The city manager may discontinue treated water service to a fire protection system if: 
(1)  The city manager discovers an unauthorized connection has been made; 
(2)  Water has been used from a fire protection system for a purpose other than extinguishing a fire; 
(3)  A fire protection system has been installed or used without a meter, where a meter is required; 
(4)  A waste of water is permitted from a fire protection system through pipes or fixtures; or 
(5)  Charges for service are delinquent under section 18-22. 
(e)  Restoration of service. Upon discontinuance under subsection (d)(3), the city manager shall not restore the service until the customer remedies the problem causing discontinuance or makes application for the kind and size of meter prescribed by the city manager for the particular system. The meter will be installed at the customer's expense. 
(f)  Availability of service. Availability of treated water will depend upon water main sizes and normal operating pressures in the area where the applicant's property is located. 
(g)  Nonconforming systems. Any person modifying, changing or adding to his premises or his existing fire protection system must at that time come into compliance with the requirements of this section, if his fire protection system did not previously conform to the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.33), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-49. - Reserve water supply for boilers. 
Where city water is used to supply a boiler, the owner should provide a tank of sufficient capacity to afford a supply of at least twelve (12) hours, into which tank the service pipe will be discharged. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.34), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-50. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  Permission to use. Fire hydrants are to be opened only by authorized employees of the city's fire, water and sewer and street departments. Any other person or business that wishes to use a fire hydrant shall obtain written permission from the department of public works under the following conditions: 
(1)  A person or business requesting use of a fire hydrant shall make written application for a permit, place a deposit (to be determined by the cost of the assembly) to secure the return of the fire hydrant/backflow assembly, and pay all water use fees as adopted by the city. 
(2)  The permittee shall use a water meter furnished by the water department whenever discharging water from a fire hydrant. 
(3)  The permittee shall use a backflow preventer that is attached to the meter and is furnished by the water department. 
(4)  The permittee shall bring the meter/backflow assembly to the water department either on or between the tenth and the fifteenth of each month for reading by utility billing at city hall. If the fifteenth is on a weekend or holiday, the meter shall be brought to utility billing at city hall on the next business day. 
(5)  The permittee shall keep the permit tag and backflow test tag attached to the fire hydrant meter assembly at all times. 
(6)  The permittee shall only use an approved spanner wrench and replace all caps on the outlets when not in use. 
(b)  Improper use. Failure to abide by the conditions of subsection (a) is sufficient cause to retain the deposit, prohibit the further use of a fire hydrant and to refuse to grant subsequent permits for use of a fire hydrant. 
(1)  A person or business commits an offense if they knowingly: 
a.  Use water from a fire hydrant without a permit from the water department/public works department; 
b.  Tamper with the fire hydrant meter or the backflow assembly in any way including the removal of the backflow preventer at anytime; or 
c.  Violate any terms and/or conditions of a permit granted under this section. 
(2)  [Reserved.] 
(c)  Exceptions. This section does not apply to: 
(1)  A city employee engaged in work in his official capacity, or 
(2)  A person or business using water from a fire hydrant for a public works department construction project under section 18-54. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.35), 3-14-89; Ord. No. 96-279, § 1, 6-11-96; Ord. No. 97-330, § 1, 8-26-97; Ord. No. 99-438, § 1, 7-13-99)  
Sec. 18-51. - Private water mains or systems. 
(a)  Mains are property of city. Water and wastewater mains, pipes and appurtenances laid in streets, alleys, or other public rights-of-way within the city immediately become property of the city upon their acceptance, except for mains, pipes and appurtenances laid within the city by governmental entities pursuant to a license granted by the city. Water and wastewater mains, pipes and appurtenances laid within the city and connected to the water or wastewater systems must be constructed under department supervision and in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Nonconforming mains. The city manager may refuse application for service to premises inside or outside of the city if, upon examination, the mains, private water lines or laterals, valves, appurtenances, fire hydrants or other equipment serving the premises are of such quality, size or installation as will not comply with the general standards and specifications of the department. 
(c)  Substandard laterals or water lines. The city manager may require the customer, as a precondition of continued service, to replace or repair private plumbing found to be in a substandard condition according to the plumbing code, if the substandard plumbing may cause: 
(1)  A hazard to public health; 
(2)  Damage or contamination to the water or wastewater systems; 
(3)  A substantial waste of water; or 
(4)  Introduction of extraneous water into the wastewater system. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.36), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-52. - Wastewater indemnity agreements. 
(a)  Grounds for denial of wastewater service. Wastewater service to premises inside or outside the city must be denied if: 
(1)  The premises are subject to frequent severe flooding; 
(2)  The wastewater main serving the premises surcharges or overflows due to infiltration of groundwater from the premises; or 
(3)  The premises are subject to being flooded by a surcharged wastewater main due to the elevation of the premises in relation to the actual or proposed wastewater main. 
(b)  Indemnity agreement. Notwithstanding subsection (a), the city manager may provide wastewater service where these conditions exist if the owner agrees in writing to defend and indemnify the city and save it whole and harmless against all damages, costs and expenses caused by the surcharging, backflow or overflow of the wastewater main serving the premises. 
(c)  Effect of agreement. The indemnity agreement, when executed by the owner, constitutes a covenant running with the land binding upon the owner, his heirs, successors and assigns. The agreement must be approved as to form by the city attorney and must be filed in the deed records of the county in which the premises is located. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.37), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-53. - Exposing meters or hydrants to damage; notice of work affecting systems; moving meters or hydrants. 
(a)  Exposure to damage. A person shall not build a driveway, sidewalk or other improvement that: 
(1)  Exposes a meter, fire hydrant, air valve, tap, pressure recording instrument, cleanout or other appurtenance to damage from vehicular traffic; or 
(2)  Causes obstruction of access to a meter, fire hydrant, air valve, tap, pressure recording instrument, cleanout or other appurtenance for operation, repair, inspection or maintenance purposes. 
(b)  Notice of work affecting systems. A person who does work of any nature on a street, alley or sidewalk within the city must notify the director at least ten (10) days in advance of the removal, raising or lowering of any part of the water or wastewater systems that may interfere with the work. Where the director is not notified, damage to any part of the systems resulting from the work will be charged against the person or his agents performing the work. 
(c)  Request to move appurtenance. The owner or occupant of premises adversely affected by the location of a meter, fire hydrant, air valve, tap, pressure recording instrument or other appurtenance may make written application to the director to have the device moved under the following conditions: 
(1)  The director may approve the application if he determines that the move will not interfere with normal department operations and will not cause damage to the water or wastewater systems. 
(2)  Upon approval of the application, the director will furnish the applicant an estimate of costs to move the device. The applicant shall bear all estimated moving costs. 
(3)  Upon deposit of the estimated costs by the applicant, the department will make the agreed-to change in location. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.38), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-54. - Water used for construction work. 
(a)  When water is free. The director may furnish water free of charge to: 
(1)  A contractor or other person performing construction work for the department; or 
(2)  A licensed plumber performing a pressure test of a private plumbing system, which test has been authorized in advance by the director. 
(b)  Other construction work. For any construction work other than that described in subsection (a), the charge for water used will be in accordance with the rates specified in section 18-34, and will be charged against the person using the water. 
(c)  Conditions when charged. If water to be used for construction is subject to charge, the water must not be turned on until all applicable preuse charges are paid. Water service may be discontinued or application refused in the same manner as provided under section 18-22. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.39), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-55. - Liability for damages. 
(a)  City not liable. The city, the department, the director or the city manager will not be liable for personal injury, death or property damage resulting from: 
(1)  Faulty or defective private plumbing, or private plumbing not meeting the provisions of this Code; 
(2)  Defects, damage or failure of a part of the wastewater system; 
(3)  Defects, damage or failure of a part of the water system directly used for fire protection; 
(4)  Defects, damage or failure, of which the city had no actual or constructive notice, of a part of the water system not directly used for fire protection; 
(5)  Interruption or discontinuance of service, including the revocation of permits; or 
(6)  Any condition or state not caused by the city of treated or untreated water supplied to premises, including soluble or insoluble substances that may mix with the water. 
(b)  State and federal law immunity. The provisions of this section are subject to the applicable state or federal laws concerning governmental immunity and its waiver. This section must not be construed to either restrict or expand the applicability of those laws. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.40), 3-14-89)  
Sec. 18-56. - Tampering with or damaging systems; unlawful use of water; prima facie evidence. 
(a)  Tampering with or damaging system. A person commits an offense if, without the written permission of the city manager, he knowingly: 
(1)  Damages or destroys part of the water or wastewater systems; 
(2)  Tampers with part of the water or wastewater systems; or 
(3)  Damages, destroys or tampers with a fire hydrant within the city. 
(b)  Certain conditions creating prima facie evidence of tampering. For purposes of this section, it is prima facie evidence that a person has tampered under subsections (a)(2) or (a)(3) if the person is a customer, owner or person or person in control of the premises, and: 
(1)  Water is prevented from passing through a meter used or furnished by the department to supply water to the premises; 
(2)  A meter used or furnished by the department is prevented from correctly registering the quantity of water supplied to the premises; 
(3)  Water is diverted or bypassed by the use of a device, from or around a pipe, main, meter, hydrant or other connection of the department; 
(4)  A meter or service connection of the department used for service to premises is removed; or 
(5)  Wastewater is prevented or diverted from flowing from premises into the wastewater system. 
(c)  Prima facie evidence of knowledge. The existence on premises of a device used for any of the unlawful purposes stated in this section shall constitute prima facie evidence of knowledge of the unlawful purpose on the part of the customer, owner or person in control of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 89-1017, § 2(Art. IV, § 18.41), 3-14-89)  
DIVISION 4.5. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes:
